msContents.summary: The manuscript contents are catalogued in DIMEV entry http://www.dimev.net/Records.php?MSS=BodLauMis108. All items belong to the LAEME literary category.

listBibl.bibl: Horstmann, Carl. Leben Jesu: ein Fragment, und Kindheit Jesu, &c.. Müünster: Regensberg, 1873.
Horstmann, Carl. Kindheit Jesu. In Altenglische Legenden: Kindheit Jesu; Geburt Jesu; Barlaam und Josophat; St. Patrick's Fegefeuer. Paderborn: F. Schöningh, 1875.

msItem.title: St. Ursula and the Eleven Thousand Virgins
St. Edmund of Abingdon (Edme of Abingdon)
The Debate between the Body and the Soul
The Life and Passion of St. Blaise
The Life and Passion of St. Cecilia
Four lines of Middle English Verse
Allas deceyte, þat in truste ys nowe
Be þou nou&yogh;t tobolde to blame
Better ys to suffre and fortune abide
He þe wise and wel i tau&yogh;t

handNote.p: The first part of the manuscript, ff. 1r-200r written in the last quarter of the thirteenth century.
The second part of the manuscript, ff. 200v-203v written in the last quarter of the thirteenth century.
The third part of the manuscript, ff. 204r-228r written in the early thirteenth century.
The fourth part of the manuscript, ff. 204r-228r written in a compact textura hand of the early thirteenth century.

The fifth part of the manuscript, ff. 228v-237v written in the late fourteenth century in a script of the same type and date (Anglicana) as that of Cambridge, Magdalene College, Pepys, MS 2498 and London, British Library, Laud Misc. MS 622.
In the sixth part of the manuscript, the top of f. 238 is in a hand of the fifteenth century.
In the sixth part of the manuscript, the verses on the rest of f. 238 are also in a hand of the fifteenth century.
On one flyleaf, f. iii recto, a fourteenth-century hand writes a prayer in Latin.

On one flyleaf, f. iii recto, a fifteenth-century hand has written a contents list, seemingly for a different manuscript, which has been inserted within the leaf. Note: another hand (different style of final s, for example) has traced over the first few lines; whether the tracing hand has contributed writing of its own is not known.

origin.p: ff. 1-198r are written in a W Oxon dialect from around the last quarter of the thirteenth century.
ff. 204r-219v are written in a W Norfolk dialect from around c. 1300.
ff. 219v-228r are written in a W Norfolk dialect with a substratum from SE Surrey, SW Kent, or N Suffolk, from around c. 1300.
ff. 228v-237v were written around the late fourteenth century.
The verses on f. 238 were written in the fifteenth century.

provenance.p: The manuscript was owned by Henry Perveys around 1450-1475.
The manuscript was owned by William Laud in 1633.

history.acquisition: The manuscript was donated to the Bodleian Library by William Laud in 1635.

bibl.ref: All items belong to the LAEME literary category.

Complete transcription of lines 1-190 added. Some xml:ids updated. Many comments added to highlight issues for further discussion.

div1.l: And spatte a luyte on is finger and ínto is erene ít schok
h H e watte al so with ís spotle is tonge  o O pene þíne mouth he seide
speche and herínge hím cam anon  þat was a swete dede
In an ensaumple þer of I i n maní stude  &yogh;wane childꝛen i baptizede beoz
Þe preost heom cro&ydot;sez míd ís spotle  ase we ofte ísez
OꝚe louerd pꝛechede wide about and muche folke hím &slong;iwede fa&slong;te
so longe þat heo ofhongrede weren  wel &slong;oꝛe at þe laste
Ich habbe gret píte oꝛe louerd &slong;eide  þat þis folk nadde íete
f F oꝛ þreo dawe&slong; heo habbez í&slong;íwed me  and nou&yogh;t ne hebbeth to mete

h H ou &slong;cholde we louerd ín wilderne&slong;&slong; &punctelev; i&slong; de&slong;cíple&slong; &slong;ede

ore louerd heom axede hou maní loue&slong; &punctelev; to &slong; muche folk heo hadde

Þo het ore louerd þat folk sitte &punctelev; and heo seten adoun echon
And blessede þe seue loues &punctelev; and let heom dele a non
h H eo eten and maden heom wel glade &punctelev; &slong;íx þou&slong;end men þare were
In none &slong;tude þare heo hadden íbeo &punctelev; neuere &slong;o ifedde heo nere
Þo heo weren folle and glade al&slong;o &punctelev; o&rrot;e louerd het anon rí&yogh;t þere
To gaderí þat releef ínto ba&slong;cate&slong; &punctelev; þat ít fo&rrot; lor&rrot; nere
Seue ba&slong;cate&slong; folle heo gadereden ; of releef after mete
Of þulke seue loue&slong; þo al þat folk &punctelev; so wel hadde í ete
O&Rrot;e louerd wende &slong;ethþe ínto þo se &punctelev; with ís de&slong;cíple&slong; alone
h H eo nadden with hem bote anne lof &punctelev; þare fo&rrot;e heo careden ech one
Sethþe þo heo afingrede weren &punctelev; bí tuene heom heo &slong;peke fa&slong;te
h H ou heo mí&yogh;ten do wíth oute mete &punctelev; fo&rrot; þe lof ne mí&yogh;te nou&yogh;t longe ílaste
Wel wu&slong;te o&rrot;e louerd al heo&rrot;e þou&yogh;t; &punctelev; &yogh;wy d&rrot;ede &yogh;e he &slong;ede
Ouwer bileue &yogh;wane &yogh;e caríeth &punctelev; fo&rrot; defaute of b&rrot;ede
Ne fedde ich nou&yogh;t fíjf þousent men &punctelev; with fíjf loues In wilderne&slong;&slong;e
And six þousend men wíth &slong;eue loue&slong; &punctelev; þo heo weren in de&slong;tresse
Þo&rrot;u&yogh; þe grace þat god heom &yogh;af &punctelev; I i nou&yogh; heo hadden ecchone
On þis o lof ín þe se &punctelev; þat heo ne maden non mo&rrot;e mone
In þat t&ydot;me ase o&rrot;e louerd eode aboute &punctelev; ane blínde man to hím men brou&yogh;te
Þat &yogh;are hadde blind ibeo &punctelev; and longe ore louerd he sou&yogh;te
In is ei&yogh;ene ore louerd spatte &punctelev; and axede &yogh;weþer he mi&yogh;te iseo
&yogh;e louerd! he seide ich iseo ane man: me þinchez ase it were a treo

And he ísaí&yogh; &slong;wíþe wel ; þe ferre and þe neí&yogh;e
Ore louerd wende mid is de&slong;cíple&slong; &punctelev; I i nto p P hílipes londe

&yogh;wí &slong;eggez men o&rrot;e louerd seíde þat ích am louerd &punctelev; þo seíden hu&ydot; ech on

And maníe þat þou art an oþur &pflour; pro phete &punctelev; among men here ícome

note.p: The Bodleian Library stamp and declaration of ownership by Archbishop Laud are currently recorded in the <facsimile> section.

div1.l: t T ellez me nouþe quad ore louerd&punctelev; &yogh;wat 3e &slong;eggez bí me
b B ote þou art gode&slong; &slong;one quath &slong;eínt p P eter&punctelev; and þat ich &slong;egge bi þe
p P eter p P eter ore louerd &slong;eide&punctelev; iblessed þou art íwis
f F or þat ne &slong;chewede noþur fle&slong;ch ne blod&punctelev; acke mi fader þat ín heuene ís;
And al þat þou bíndest on eorþe&punctelev; ín heuene ít worth íbounde
Acke þat ne tel þou no man&punctelev; for þe &slong;oþe þou hast ífonnde
And I i n heuene ít worth on bounde also&punctelev; þat þou unbíndest here
þat power he &yogh;af p P eter þo&punctelev; and alle ís oþere fere

And alle þe p p&combtildevert; pre latu&slong; of holíe churche : þat after him &slong;ethþe come; The word "holie" in this line represents the scribe's frequent tendency to place the acute-like i-dot over the following glyph. I have not attempted to represent this in the transcriptions. It seems to me that it is best associated with the facsimile layer.
þ Þ arefo&rrot;e ech man heom &slong;cholde a bowíe : þat guode &yogh;eme þarof nome

p P eter p P eter o&rrot;e louerd &slong;eíde,&punctelev; to IJ erusalem í mot wende There are two folds running down the middle of the parchment from the top of the text down to poetic) line 56 on the left and poetic line 79 on the right. In most cases, there is no uncertainty about the reading but the "s" in "seide" in this line is the first where it needs to be noted. I have not indicated letters affected by these folds unless they are considerably obscured. This note should probably be moved (to right before the next <pb/> element?).
And soffrí muche fo&rrot; mankuínde&punctelev; and þane deth aten ende

s S
Seínt Peter him ladde in conseílle,&punctelev; and seíde louerd þín ore
h H ít ne falleth nou&yogh;t þe swuch þíng to done&punctelev; man to bugge &slong;o &slong;o&rrot;e

g G o bí h&ydot;nde me o&rrot;e louerd &slong;eíde&punctelev; þou spext a&slong;e mí fo The fold in the parchment hides the "i" in "seide", but the acute-like dot is visible over the "d", confirming the reading.

þ þ ou no&slong;t nou&yogh;t &yogh;wat to gode bifallez&punctelev; ne onder&slong;tonde&slong;t no þe mo This line and the following three lines have a corrupt tile in the digital image. Readings should be checked against the TIFF file.

h H o &slong;o co
cometh after me&punctelev; hím &slong;eelf he mot fo&rrot;&slong;ake The tip of a large triangular hole in the manuscript begins after the first two letters in "cometh". The scribe appears to have begun the word and then thought better of it, starting the word anew on the other side of the hole without erasing the inital "co" he had already written.
h H ís O o wene rode bere and s&ydot;wí me&punctelev; and he wolle to me take
h H o &slong;o wole ís &slong;oule &slong;auuí&punctelev; he a&slong; mot allinge fo&rrot; leo&slong;e
And ho &slong;o leo&slong;t is &slong;oule he a&slong;&slong;auez;&punctelev; nou ma&ydot; ech man cheo&slong;e
And apeiri ís &slong;elíe &slong;oule&punctelev; me þ&ydot;nchez he bí &yogh;ít wel lu&ydot;te
f F o&rrot; god wole comen atþe la&slong;te&punctelev; and &yogh;íuen euer ech man
After þath he hat here ídon&punctelev; a&slong;e euene a&slong;e he can

After síx dawes þere afterward&punctelev; o&rrot;e louerd ope ane heí&yogh;e hulle gan gon The main body of the ornamental capital drops into line 71, but the left downward strok of the "A" actually descends to the left of the text down to line 80.
s S eint p P eter he nam wíth hím&punctelev; and &slong;eínt I J eme an &slong;eínt I J ohan
A non &slong;o he was þudere ícome&punctelev; is cloþes schynen þere
b B rí&yogh;to&rrot;e þane euere aní &slong;onne &slong;chon;&punctelev; &yogh;wíte ís cloþes were
þ Þ ere comen tweí &pflour; pro phete&slong;&punctelev; Mo&ydot;&slong;es and h H el&ydot;e

And &slong;peken wíth o&rrot;e louerd I̅u Jesu
c Cri &slong;t&punctelev; þe maydene&slong; &slong;one Maríe I have used the combining mark ̅ for the abbreviation of Jesu, since the stroke does not cross the "h"; it is more like a macron between the "h" and the following vowel. The abbreviation of "Crist" looks like "c" with a minim directly above it. I have used  &openparen;COMBINING LATIN SMALL LETTER DOTLESS I&closeparen; for this mark, but note that this is a PRIVATE USE AREA code point.
Nu&slong;te no man &yogh;wat ít wa&slong;&punctelev; þat con&slong;eíl longe íla&slong;te;
s S eínt Peter hadde wonder þarof&punctelev; and bíheold wel fa&slong;te
o to þe an oþur to Mo&ydot;ses&punctelev; þe þrídde to h H el&ydot;se
þ Þ o &slong;eínt p P eter hadde í&slong;eíd þís word&punctelev; ne mí&yogh;te heom no man íseo Horstmann (p. 32) claims that "Peter fehlt in Ms", but it is clearly there.
þ Þ are cam a&slong;e þeí ít a cloude were &punctelev; and ouer ca&slong;te hem alle þ&rrot;eo
A voíz he heo&rrot;de of heuene þo&punctelev; þat þeos wo&rrot;des gan &slong;ínge
þ Þ í&slong; í&slong; mí leoue &slong;one þat í&slong; me leof&punctelev; In hím ís al mí lík&ydot;nge
þ Þ are na&slong; non þat mí&yogh;te &slong;tonde&punctelev; heo nu&slong;ten &yogh;ware heo were
þ Þ o í&slong;ei&yogh;en heo o&rrot;e louerd allone&punctelev; nou&yogh;t elle&slong; ne mí&yogh;ten heo &slong;eo

Ne tellez noman o&rrot;e louerd &slong;eíde&punctelev; of þis príuet e é
Note that French stressed final "e" is represented with an acute accent in the critical transcription.
Are ch beo to heuene i went þat &yogh;e ne &slong;eon nou&yogh;t me
A&slong;e þeos de&slong;ciple&slong; to gadere weren heo maden contek and mone Lines 89-90 appear to omit the acute-like dot over i in a systematic manner.

l.note: Approximately 22 lines are missing from the beginning of the page. At this point, a small piece of parchment still bound contains an unidentifiable fragment of an ornamental capital in blue ink, touched with red. Beneath it, presumably the following line is a capital "A", touched with red. Were these remnants to be lineated, they would presumably be lines 103-104, and this is indicated in their @xml:id, albeit with a suffix "a" so that the current lineation can be preserved. If Horstmann transcribed these fragments, they were lost in our OCR.
Another 27 or so lines have been lost due to the tearing of the page. Another fragment remains, probably starting with part of a capital "A" at line 131a.

l.unclear: ut þa oþur bit at þ
l.note: Lines 132a-135a are incomplete, as the parchment is torn on the right before the caesura. Line 132a is torn at more or less the point where the ascenders of letters begin. The presence of distinct thorn descenders make it possible to read the text with some confidence, the least distinct letters being the "b" in "bit", which might be an "s", and the "t" in "at".

div1.l:
þ Þ e oþur wolle ari&slong;e and late lette
Horstmann's emendation of "late" to "lette" may just be an accurate reading of a ligatured or crowded "ett".
Al&slong;o ít fareth of ouwer neode
And &slong;tudefa&slong;tlíche wíth gode

l.note: The folio is torn, with only fragments of lines 177a-180a remaining. There is evidence of about ten letters (including two spaces) in line 177a, but they are all but unreadable.

OO R r re lou &combtildevert; er d wende aboute and prechede þat folk&punctelev; and &slong;eíde hem an&slong;aumple&slong; fale

Ake &slong;íte fo&rrot;to þou beo herre ícleped&punctelev; I i n þe lowe&slong;te &slong;tude

f F o&rrot; mo&rrot;e man&slong;chípe ít ís to beon ícleped&punctelev; fram lowe &slong;tude an heí&yogh;
f F o&rrot; ech man þat hím an hau&slong;ez here&punctelev; I i lowed he &slong;chal beo
And ech man þat hím lowez here&punctelev; anhau&slong;ed man &slong;chal hím í&slong;eo
Ne þie kun ne ríche men&punctelev; þat wolleth ít &yogh;elde þe here
Acke M m ake þíne gíftníngue of pouere M m en &punctelev; and of feble M m en al&slong;o
þ Þ at þou mouwe ín heuene þíne mede afongue&punctelev; þat þou ha&slong;t fo&rrot; hem ido
¶ þ Þ o p&rrot;echede o&rrot;e louerd &slong;unfule M m en&punctelev; to leten heore &slong;unfole dede Is there any issue with using o3 for a pilcrow?
And come tamendement wíth þou&yogh;t and hope;&punctelev; and þere ane bítabítale heom &slong;ede&punctelev;

A riche M m an hadde tweí &rrot;one&slong;&punctelev; þe eldore wa&slong; e&ydot;r of ís londe To the left of this line part of the previous folio is to be visible, apparently sewn to far into the bindings. An unidentifiable part of an ornamental capital in blue ink may be seen. Just to the right and below is what might be the downward stroke of an "s", "&yogh;", or "A", and beneath that there is an identifiable "A".
Of þe &yogh;ongo&rrot;e þat herítage nadde&punctelev; he gan hím onder&slong;tonde
And &yogh;af hím tre&slong;o&rrot; rí&yogh;t ínou&yogh;&punctelev; I i n to an oþer contreíe to fare
And líbbe þere bí ís M m archaundíse&punctelev; I i n richesse wíthoute care
þ Þ o he cam I i n to ane oþur contreíe &punctelev; is catel to bí &slong;ette A smudge over the "i" in "is" makes it impossible to tell whether or not the "i" is dotted.
In hem and ín oþere folíes&punctelev; ís tre&slong;o&rrot; &slong;one he &slong;pende
So þat he bícam a wrechche&punctelev; and beggare aten ende
h H e wu&slong;te wel þat ís fader wa&slong; ríche&punctelev; A a ke he ne do&rrot;&slong;te to hím wende
f F o&rrot; he hadde &slong;o follíche ído&punctelev; la&slong;te he wolde hím &slong;chende
Ake naþele&slong; he þou&yogh;te on ku&ydot;ndhede þat M m an hath to í&slong; chílde
And þat ku&ydot;nde blod ít wole &yogh;íue&punctelev; þat he were hím euere mílde
s S o þat he dude hím an A a unter&punctelev; and hom to í&slong; fader íwende
f F ul so&rrot;e he d&rrot;adde to comen hím neíí&yogh;;&punctelev; ake anon &slong;o ís fader of hím wu&slong;te
h H e o&rrot;n a&yogh;eín hím wíth grete I J oíe&punctelev; and biclupte hím and cu&slong;te
f F ader mercí þís oþur &slong;eíde&punctelev; &yogh;w&ydot;&rrot;þe nam ích nou&yogh;t

And &slong;eíden &yogh;wat &slong;ígne ha&slong;tou fo&rrot; þe &punctelev; þat þou þu&slong; mí&yogh;t do
b B ríngez þe temple o&rrot;e louerd &slong;eíde &punctelev; &yogh;if &yogh;e wollez to grounde
And Ich ich a&slong; wolle þane þ&rrot;idde da&ydot; &punctelev; arere op In in one &slong;tounde
b B i þe temple of ís owene bodí &punctelev; þat wo&rrot;d he hath í&slong;eíd

þ Þ at he woldsuperscript e
a rere arere up þane þridde daí &punctelev; after þat he wa&slong; ded

þ Þ e gíwe&slong; Gíwe&slong;
onder &slong;stoden onder&slong;toden bí þe grete temple &punctelev; þat heo Inne inne were
h H ov mi&yogh;te ít beo heo &slong;eíden þat þís Man man &punctelev; fals and luþer nere
f F o&rrot; a bu&ydot;ldínge heo wa&slong; &slong;íxe and fourtí &yogh;er &punctelev; and &yogh;eot mo&rrot;e In in þe &yogh;ere
&YOGH;wam þenchez hím &slong;ulue make &punctelev; þat &slong;o &slong;one a&slong; wolde arere
Some &slong;eíden þat he wa&slong; g&ydot;lour &slong;trong &punctelev; &slong;ome þat he wa&slong; guod
þ Þ o gan o&rrot;e louerd prechí of clergíe &punctelev; and hadeliche fo&rrot;th &slong;tod
Mí clergíe ne cometh nou&yogh;t of me o&rrot;e louerd sede &punctelev; ac of hím þat me hidere &slong;ende&slong;ende goes into gutter
h H ou can he of clergíe þís oþur &slong;eíden &punctelev; to &slong;chole neuere he ne wende
&YOGH;wí a wa&ydot;tíe me fo&rrot; to quelle o&rrot;e louerd &slong;ede &punctelev; &yogh;wat habbe ích ou mí&slong;do

I&slong; þe deuel on þe erasure under "giwes"
giwes Giwes &slong;eíden &punctelev; ho a waítíez awaítíez þe &slong;o

&YOGH;e beoth wroþe fo&rrot; ich helde men &punctelev;
In in þe sabat o&rrot;e louerd &slong;eide
N e &slong;eith e &slong;eith nou&yogh;t ouwer lawe of Mo&ydot;ses &punctelev; &yogh;wane &yogh;e þaro wollez rede
þ Þ at &yogh;e &slong;chullen beo Icírcumcízed círcumcízed &punctelev; þene eí&yogh;tiþe daí þat &yogh;e í bore íbore beth
þ Þ eí ít falle on a sabat &punctelev; a&slong;e &yogh;e aldaí í &slong;eoth í&slong;eoth

þ Þ e &slong;oule bote and þe bodíe&slong; &punctelev;
In in þe sabat do
And þerof ne &slong;eggez nouþe neuere a wo&rrot;d &punctelev; of al þat he a&yogh;en hem tellez
þ Þ at o&rrot;e louerd were p&rrot;íuelíche ínome &punctelev; þat folk þar of ne &slong;peke
W with oute withoute con&slong;eílle of &slong;ome of hís &punctelev; heo ne do&rrot;&slong;ten bí gínne bígínne ít nou&yogh;t

Ne In in non halídaí la&slong;te þat folk &punctelev;
In in de&slong;tourbaunce were íbrou3t

Ore louerd wende ari&yogh;t to betaníe Betaníe
and wíth S&ydot;mon lep&rrot;ou&slong; la&ydot;
To þe temple he wende a&yogh;en &punctelev; anon &slong;o it wa&slong; daí lí&yogh;t daílí&yogh;t
A&yogh;en þe heíe fe&slong;te to &slong;chewí hím &punctelev; and to í&slong; Inne inne he eode a ní&yogh;t
þ Þ e deuel þat hadde to o&rrot;e louerd onde &punctelev; he wende ínto Iuda&slong;
h H í&slong; In in wa&slong; euere a redí aredí þere &punctelev; fo&rrot; euere a &slong;chrewe he wa&slong;
h h e eggede hím þat he &slong;cholde &slong;one &punctelev; þe gíwe&slong; Gíwe&slong; o&rrot;e louerd take
þ Þ ene wodne&slong;daí þe gíwe&slong; Gíwe&slong; comen &punctelev; and míd hím þar of þarof &slong;pake
Ivda&slong; í&slong;ai heo&rrot;e grete wille &punctelev; &yogh;íf heom þare of mí&yogh;te &slong;pede
And þou&yogh;te þat he nolde hím nou&yogh;t bí take bítake &punctelev; bote heo hím &yogh;eouen ís mede

h H e þou&yogh;te on þe þ&rrot;íttí pane&slong; of teoþínge &punctelev; þat to hím wolde habbe í wend íwend
verte ad i&slong;tud &slong;ignuİ signum ✝ in i&slong;to libro in ín princípío librí
 ibi ínvenít plus de pa&slong;ione passione
dm domini po&slong;t a&slong;&slong;umptonē assumptionem
&slong;teİ sancte
maríe Marie
The scribe has rather stylised acute accents that curve down, a quality that can also be observed in his other abbreviation markers. MUFI does not appear to have exact matches. I have used the combining macron in "signum", "assumptionem", and "sancte". For "domini" and "assumptionem" the combining abbreviation mark bar above with dot and the combining curly bar above respectively, although they may be the same abbreviation mark. I am not at all sure that these are the most appropriate matches. The Latin cross (✝) is used for the "signum" to which the comment refers.

div1.head: 10 Sancta crux
div1.note: [This legend, which is counted as 10th in the MS. 1s preceded by (1) a poem on the Life and Passion of Christ (wanting the beginning and end), ed. by me under the title of 'Leben Iesu, ein Fragment,' Münster, Regensberg, 1873, and (2) by a poem on the Infancy of Christ, ed. in 'Altengl. Legenden,' Paderborn, 1875, pp. 1-61. Eight pieces, therefore, are lost before the legend of the Holy Rood.]

lg.l: ÞE holie rode ifounde was &punctelev; ase ich eov nouþe may telle
Costantyn þe Aumperour &punctelev; muche heþene folk gan aquelle
For huy ore louerd iesu crist &punctelev; to strongue deþe brou&yogh;te
And alle þe heþene men þat nei&yogh; him were &punctelev; sone he dude to nou&yogh;te
Eleyne, þat was is moder &punctelev; to Ierusalem he sende
to sechen after þe holie rode &punctelev; and heo gladliche forth iwende
Þo heo cam þudere, heo liet crie &punctelev; ase heo hire red hadde inome
Þat alle þe giwes of þe cite &punctelev; bifore hire scholden come
Þo þe giwes isomoned were &punctelev; huy hadden grete fere
gret conseil huy nomen þareof &punctelev; &yogh;wat þe enchesoun were
Þo seide on, þat hiet Iudas &punctelev; "Ich wene þat ich wot
&YOGH;wat þis somunce amounti schal &punctelev; &yogh;if þat ich ou telle mot
Ich wene þat þe quene enqueri wole &punctelev; ase heo hadde iþou&yogh;t
Aftur þe rode þat Iesu crist &punctelev; to deþe was on ibrou&yogh;t
Þat non of eov ne beo so wod &punctelev; þat þareof aknowe beo
In conseil ich eov telle wole &punctelev; þat mi fader tolde me
Þo mi fader symeon &punctelev; in is deþe vuele lay
" 'Iudas,' he seide, 'leoue sone &punctelev; &yogh;if hit bitidez so
Þat men enquerieth aftur þe rode &punctelev; þat Iesus was on ido
Loke þat þov beo aknowe þareof &punctelev; are men þe aquelle
Þat Zachee, mi fader, tolde &punctelev; in conseile ich þe telle
A luyte bifore is deþe he seide me &punctelev; þat he was atþe dede
to burie þe rode opon Caluarie hulle &punctelev; ase huy nomen heom to rede
Leoue fader, ich seide þo &punctelev; &yogh;wat eilede eov, alas
&YOGH;wy wolde &yogh;e him to deþe do &punctelev; &yogh;wane he so guod was
he seide þat þoru&yogh; him it nas nou&yogh;t &punctelev; ake for þat he withsede
Mine felawes of heore lawe &punctelev; huy duden him to deþe
And sethþe in sepulchre leiden him &punctelev; and he aros to liue
Fram deþe þene þridde day &punctelev; Mid is woundene fiue
In þe londe of Galilee &punctelev; þat muche folk it isei&yogh;
Twelf Monþe it was þareafterward &punctelev; and half &yogh;er and more
Þat Steuene, þat [was] mi broþur &punctelev; prechede of is lore
Þe Giwes him ladden withoute þe toun &punctelev; and þreowen him with stones
And þarewith brou&yogh;ten him to deþe &punctelev; and debruysden alle is bones
Þene Morewe aftur Midewinter day &punctelev; to deþe huy him brou&yogh;te
And nouþe he is in þe blisse of heuene &punctelev; and þat he wel deore a|bou&yogh;te.' "
¶ Þo Iudas hadde þis tale itold &punctelev; þe giwes seiden, ase huy stode
"Neuer er ne heorde we telle &punctelev; þus muche of þe rode."
Þo þe tyme icome was, &punctelev; bifore þe quyene huy come
"Cheoseth," seide þe Quiene anon &punctelev; "on of þis tweie domes
Lijf and deth eov is bifore &punctelev; cheosez &yogh;weþur &yogh;e wolle
bote &yogh;e me bringue þe holie rode &punctelev; echone brenne &yogh;e schulle."
gret fuyr heo liet makie &punctelev; ri&yogh;t bifore hore ei&yogh;en
Þe giwes bigonne to crien loude &punctelev; þo huy þat fuyr isei&yogh;en
For Zachee, is fader fader &punctelev; of swyþe gret power was
Þulke tyme þat Iesus &punctelev; was opon þe rode ido."
Þo liet þe Quiene nime Iudas &punctelev; and alle þe oþere he[= heo] liet go
And bad him beo aknowe anon. &punctelev; he nolde for no þretningue
Þe Quiene him liet wel faste binde &punctelev; and in strongue prisone bringue
Withoute mete and drinke &punctelev; þare seue dawes he lay
For strong hounguer he criede loude &punctelev; þene seuenþe day
Þare ich wene þat þe rode beo &punctelev; ase mi fader me seide."
Þo he out of prisone cam &punctelev; with muche folk he wende
to þe place þare þe rode was &punctelev; ase is fader him kende
Þo he to þe place cam &punctelev; adoun he sat akneo
"Louerd," he[MS. heo] seide, "&yogh;if it is soth &punctelev; þat þou man and god beo
And þat þou of Marie were ibore &punctelev; siend us þine grace
Som tokningue, þat we finde mowe · þe rode in þis place."
Anon so Iudas þis bone hadde &punctelev; to ore louerd ibede
Þe hul bigan to quakien &punctelev; and out of one stude
A smoke þare cam and wende an hei&yogh; &punctelev; and muche place fulde
Swottore þing nas neuere non &punctelev; þane þat smoke[MS. smake] smulde
þo Iudas þis isei&yogh; &punctelev; loude he gan to crie
"Iesus is on Almi&yogh;ti god &punctelev; ibore he was of þe maydene Marie
he is wod þat ani oþur bileuez &punctelev; ase ich habbe mani a day
Taken ichulle cristindom &punctelev; ich forsake here þe giwene lay."
he liet him cristni hasteliche &punctelev; and þo he icristned was
He liet him nenne Quiriac &punctelev; þat erore hiet Iudas
Þo nomen huy spade and schouele &punctelev; and ner þe place wende
And bigonne forto deluen deope &punctelev; þare ase þe smoke out kende
So þat huy founden roden þreo &punctelev; þo huy hadden idolue longue
Þe rode þat god was on ido &punctelev; and þat þe tweie þeoues weren on an|honge
biside ore louerd, him forto schiende. &punctelev; þo nusten huy of þe þreo
Þo holie croyz þat huy sou&yogh;ten &punctelev; &yogh;wich it mi&yogh;te beo
Naþeles huy nomen alle þreo &punctelev; and toward toune heom bere
To Dame Heleyne, þe guode Quene &punctelev; with wel glade chere
bi þe weye ase huy comen &punctelev; men gonne a&yogh;ein heom bringue
A ded &yogh;ong man ope one bere &punctelev; toward bure&yogh;ingue
Quiriac nam þat o rode &punctelev; and efftsone þat oþur
And leide opon þat dede man &punctelev; ake he ne aros for noþur
Þe þridde huy leide opon him &punctelev; and he aros wel bliue
And þonkede &yogh;eorne godes sone &punctelev; þat fram deþe him brou&yogh;te to liue
Þo cam þe deouel &yogh;eollinde forth &punctelev; loude he gan to grede
"Alas, nouþe [is] mi power idon &punctelev; eueref[t] more," he sede
"Iesus, Iesus, &yogh;wat, þenxt þou &punctelev; al folk to þe lede
Þou hauest here men to warde i&yogh;iue &punctelev; þing þat ich mest drede
Þoru&yogh; &yogh;wan ich was furst ouercome &punctelev; ake nouþe ich am al at grounde
Alas þulke soruwe &punctelev; þat heo euere was ifounde
For ine habbe power non so gret &punctelev; on eorþe among manne
&YOGH;if man fourmeth enes þe croyz &punctelev; anon þat ine mot þanne
Þarefore ich wot þat euerech man &punctelev; wole nou þe soþe ise
Þat þe croiz me hauez ouercome &punctelev; and al bileue me
Allas, alas þe time, i sei&yogh;e &punctelev; al ich worþe nouþe forsake
Iudas, Iudas, &yogh;wat was þe &punctelev; hou hauest þou on itake
Þoru&yogh; A Iudas, þat was &yogh;wilene &punctelev; Iesus to deþe ich brou&yogh;te
And nov þoru&yogh; Iudas ouercome ich am &punctelev; and ibrou&yogh;t to nou&yogh;te
Strencþe ne worth me neuereft non &punctelev; bote ani man wolle with wille
Serui me to paye is flesch &punctelev; is soule forto spille
Nouþe mi strencþe is me binome &punctelev; fondi ich mot with ginne
And with traisun, &yogh;if ich mai &punctelev; ani man to me iwinne
Ine may here no leng bileue &punctelev; for þis me þinchez longue
For þe creoiz þat me is so nei&yogh; &punctelev; in pine ich am ful strongue."
IVdas seide: "go heonne anon &punctelev; and ne cum[MS. ne cum he cum] here nonmore
Ifounde is, þei it late beo &punctelev; þat schal ouercome al þi lore
He þat haueth here þis dede man &punctelev; fram deþe ibrou&yogh;t to liue
Pulte þe and þi pouwer al &punctelev; into helle grounde bliue."
Muche was þe Ioye of þe croyz &punctelev; þat men maden þo þere
With gret song and with processioun &punctelev; to þe Quiene huy hire bere
Þo nam Iudas cristindom &punctelev; and þo he ibaptized was
he liet him cleopien Quiriac &punctelev; þat erore hiet Iudas
Þe Quiene of seluer and of gold &punctelev; one riche schrine heo wrou&yogh;te
And deorewurthe &yogh;imstones &punctelev; and þe Rode þareinne[MS. innne] heo brou&yogh;te
Opon þe hulle of caluarie &punctelev; þare huy þe rode founde
A noble churche heo dude arere &punctelev; Ihered beo þulke stounde
Þo wilnede þe Quene muche &punctelev; After þe nayles þreo
&YOGH;warewith ore louerd was &punctelev; inailed to þe treo
Quiriac, þat hiet er Iudas &punctelev; wende to þe place
Þare ase þe croiz ifounde was &punctelev; and bad ore louerdes grace
Þat he, &yogh;if is wille were &punctelev; þe þre Nailes him sende
Þe Nailes with li&yogh;tingue gret &punctelev; op of þe eorþe wenden
Quiriac þonkede Ihesu crist &punctelev; and with gret Ioye heom nam
And bitok heom heleyne, þe guode Quene &punctelev; þo he to hire cam
Þus was þe holie Rode ifounde &punctelev; þe þridde day of May
Þat we holdez in holi churche &punctelev; þe holie rodeday
Quiriac, þat þe rode fond &punctelev; sethþe bischop was
he is nouþe in heouene seint Quiriac &punctelev; þat erore hiet Iudas
biseche we þe holie croiz &punctelev; þat brou&yogh;te þane Deuel to grounde
And seint Quiriac and seinte heleyne &punctelev; þoru&yogh; &yogh;wam heo was ifounde
Þat huy bisechen him for us &punctelev; þat on þe Rode schedde is blod
Þat we moten to þe Ioye come &punctelev; of heuene þat is so guod
ÞOrou&yogh; a treo we weren furlore &punctelev; and furst ibrou&yogh;t to grounde
And þoru&yogh; a treo to liue ibrou&yogh;t &punctelev; ihered beo þulke stounde
Al it[MS. A lit] cam of one more &punctelev; þat us to deþe brou&yogh;te
And þat us brou&yogh;te to liue a&yogh;en &punctelev; þoru Iesus þat us bou&yogh;te
Of þe Appeltreo þat ore furste fader &punctelev; þane Appel of nam
In þe manere þat ich ov telle wole &punctelev; þe swete rode cam
Þo Adam, ore furste fader &punctelev; þe sunne hadde ido
Idriue he was out of parays &punctelev; and eue, is wijf, also
Aftur milce &yogh;eorne he cride &punctelev; þei it to late were
For one biheste þat he of ore louerd hadde &punctelev; þo þe Aungel him drof out þere
Þat, &yogh;wane þe time were folfuld &punctelev; ore louerd him wolde biþenche
And with Oyle of milce smeorien him &punctelev; and is sunnes aquenche
gret hope hadde Adam to his biheste &punctelev; þereafter eueremo
Ase he in þe ualeye of Ebron &punctelev; leouede with teone and wo
Twei sones he hadde &punctelev; þat hei&yogh;ten Caym and Abel
For onde þe on aslou&yogh; þat oþur &punctelev; ase &yogh;e iwuten it wel
Þo Caym hadde is broþer aslawe &punctelev; iflemd he was þarefore
And þo Adam isai&yogh; þat he hadde &punctelev; beie is sones forlore
he weop and made deol inou&yogh; &punctelev; "louerd," he seide, "þin ore
Nei&yogh; womman ich habbe to muche ibeo &punctelev; inelle nei&yogh; hire come non|more
And nouþe mine sones, a weilawei! &punctelev; and of alle womman[MS. wommen] is more."
Þo nolde Adam come nei&yogh; is wijf &punctelev; to hundrede &yogh;er and more
For wo þat he hadde for hire ihaued &punctelev; euere he liuede in sore
Of ore louerd he hadde tockningue sethþe &punctelev; þat he scholde to is wiue wiende
Þo ne dorste he nou&yogh;t þarea&yogh;ein beo. &punctelev; a child he hadde atþenende
Seth: he liet it cleopie &punctelev; and sethþe he hadde mo
Al is lijf þe selie man &punctelev; leouede in teone and wo
Þo he was of Nin houndret &yogh;er &punctelev; and to and þritti old
Þe strencþe him failede in is limes &punctelev; is bodi bicam al cold
he ne mi&yogh;te nou&yogh;t aboute þe eorþe swinke &punctelev; ne þe weodes up drawe
Of is lijf he was anuyd &punctelev; and wolde beo ded wel fawe
he sat and carede of is lijf &punctelev; he cleopede is sone Seth
"leoue sone," he seide, "ich am weri of leoued &punctelev; and wilni muche mi dez
Þo ich was out of parays idriue &punctelev; ore louerd bihiet me þere
With eoyle of milce to smeorie me &punctelev; &yogh;wane it time were
So longue ich habbe þare abede &punctelev; þat ine may libbe more
to parays þov most þareaftur go &punctelev; and bidde him milce and ore
Þe Aungel þov schalt þare finde &punctelev; þat drof me fram þe &yogh;ate
Seie, ich abide þulke biheste &punctelev; and me þinchez it comez to late
And seie, elde me hath ouercome &punctelev; þat Ine may libbe longue
bide him þat ich dei&yogh;e mote &punctelev; and þe eoyle of milce afongue."
"Ine can nanne wei," quath is sone &punctelev; "þuderward, ase ich wene."
"Leoue sone," Adam seide &punctelev; "þe wei is wel isene
&YOGH;wane þou comest to þe heued of þis valeie &punctelev; a grene wei þov schalt wiende
Þat gez euene ri&yogh;t puyr est &punctelev; and to parays gez þat on ende
Þareforth comen þi moder an ich &punctelev; þo ich parays forliet
Euerech stape þat we stepen &punctelev; forbarnde onder ore fet
Ne mi&yogh;te þare neuereeft gras on growe &punctelev; and al þe wei elles is grene
For þe foule sunnes þat we duden &punctelev; ore stapen beoth euere isene
Þare þov mi&yogh;t withoute faille &punctelev; to parays euene gon."
Seth nam is fader blessingue &punctelev; and wende him forth anon
Þe stapen he fond forwelewede &punctelev; ase is fader him sede
Þo he to þe &yogh;ate cam, &punctelev; he ne dorste gon in for drede
An Aungel cam sone to[MS. te?] [þe] &yogh;ate &punctelev; and axede &yogh;wat he sou&yogh;te
he seide þat one tiþingue to him &punctelev; fram is fader he brou&yogh;te
Þat he wes old and weri of leoued &punctelev; and þat he was oflongued sore
After þe biheste þat him was bihote &punctelev; for he ne mi&yogh;te libbe nonmore
¶ "&YOGH;e," seide þe Aungel, "is he so? &punctelev; he ne schal þarof nou&yogh;t doute
pult in þin heued here atþe &yogh;ate &punctelev; and stond þisulf withoute!"
So gret deli&yogh;t he hadde and Ioye &punctelev; of þe foulene murie song
A grene he isai&yogh; of grete swotnesse &punctelev; and faire flovres þare among
Ech manere fruyt þare he isai&yogh; &punctelev; þat smulde also wel swote
him þou&yogh;te of eche manere vuel &punctelev; Aman mi&yogh;te habbe is bote
him þou&yogh;te, &yogh;if he moste þere &punctelev; biholden In anie stounde
he mi&yogh;te euere in Ioye libbe &punctelev; and is limes beon hole and sounde
Amidde þe place, þat was so fair &punctelev; he sai&yogh; a swiþe fair welle
Fram &yogh;wam alle þe wateres on eorþe comiez &punctelev; ase þe boc us dez telle
Ouer þe welle þare stod a treo &punctelev; with bowes brode and lere
Ake þare nas opon noþur lief ne rinde &punctelev; bote ase it foroldet were
An Addre it hadde biclupt aboute &punctelev; al naked withoute skinne
Þat was þat treo and þe Naddre &punctelev; þat made Adam don furst[orig. þe] sunne
Faire ileued and iwoxe &punctelev; op to þe heouene an hei&yogh;
Þe More of þe treo, ase him þou&yogh;te &punctelev; tilde into helle grounde
Godes sone[MS. sone sone] it was, þat on eorþe &punctelev; for þine fader sunnes wole beo
And bringue with him þe eoyle of milce &punctelev; &yogh;wane þe tyme ifuld is
to smeorie þarewith and bringe of pine &punctelev; þine fader and alle his."
Þo wende þe Aungel to þulke treo &punctelev; Ane Appel þareof he nam
And bitok Seth þreo curneles þarof &punctelev; þo he to him cam
And bad him legge þulke kurneles &punctelev; onder is fader toungue
&YOGH;wane he were ded, and burien him &punctelev; and lokie &yogh;wat þarof sprongue
¶ Seth wende hamward ase he cam &punctelev; þe wei was wel isene
For he isei&yogh; þe stapen þat weren ibrende &punctelev; and þat oþur wei was al grene
Þo he was icomen hom a&yogh;en &punctelev; his fader he fond ded
he dude þe curneles onder is toungue &punctelev; ase þe Aungel him hadde ised
And sethþe he burede him in þe valeie of Ebron &punctelev; ase it was ri&yogh;t to don
And ofswonk is owene mete &punctelev; þo he nuste non oþur won
In A fewe &yogh;er þareAfturward &punctelev; þe curneles bigunne springe
Þreo smale &yogh;erdene þare woxen of &punctelev; faire þoru&yogh; alle þingue
Þo huy weren iwoxe in lengþe &punctelev; of one Elne, ich wene
In þulke stat huy stoden longue þare &punctelev; and eueremore grene
Anon forto Moyses þe profete &punctelev; &yogh;eode þare in londe
to lede þat folk of Israel. &punctelev; and þo he fond þe &yogh;erdene stonde
"lo here," he seide, "gret bitokningue &punctelev; of þe holie trinite
Of fader and sone and holie gost &punctelev; bi þeose &yogh;eorde þreo."
he tok hem op with gret honour &punctelev; and in faire cloþe heom wond
A suote smul þare cam of heom &punctelev; þat smelde into Al þat lond
to confermi þe bet is lawe &punctelev; he bar heom forth on is hond
Ech sick man þat heom Anourede &punctelev; is hele anon he fond
to techen is folk þe ri&yogh;te lawe &punctelev; þe &yogh;eordene with him he ber
And forto hele sike men &punctelev; to and fourti &yogh;er
Sethþe þo he dei&yogh;e scholde &punctelev; þe &yogh;eordene he sette er
Onder þe hulle of Tabor &punctelev; and deide himsuluen þer
Þare stoden þis &yogh;eordene grene &punctelev; more þane a þousend &yogh;er
Forto seint Daui þe kyng cam &punctelev; þat was of so gret power
So þat he was þoru&yogh; þe holie gost &punctelev; ihote forto hi&yogh;e
To þe hulle of Tabor &punctelev; in þe londe of Arabie
And þat he þulke &yogh;eordene þreo &punctelev; fette and with him nome
Nie dawes he was þuderward &punctelev; are he þudere come
With gret honur he nam heom op &punctelev; þo he þe &yogh;eordene[MS. &yogh;eordere] fond
Þe swotnesse þat þarof cam &punctelev; fulde al þat lond
With grete melodie of is harpe &punctelev; seint Daui þe &yogh;eordene nam
And ladde heom to Ierusalem &punctelev; þene Nynþe day hom he cam
In a priue stude he heom sette &punctelev; ase it was in þe eueningue
Forto amorewe, þat he isei&yogh;e &punctelev; &yogh;wodere he mi&yogh;te heom bet bringue
AMorewe, þo he cam þerto &punctelev; to one huy weren alle icome
and weren imorede suyþe faste &punctelev; þat huy ne mi&yogh;ten beo op inome
Þat huy weren so alle to one iwoxe &punctelev; &yogh;wat bitoknede þis
bote þe fader and sone and þe holie gost &punctelev; þat al o god it is
Seint Daui aboute þis holie &yogh;eorde &punctelev; a strong wal he liet arere
And nam guode &yogh;eme hov longue it woxe &punctelev; fram &yogh;ere to &yogh;ere
With a bei&yogh; of seoluer he bond &punctelev; eche &yogh;eres schute þere
Þat he mi&yogh;te atþe laste iwite &punctelev; hou old þat treo were
Ake eueremore[MS. mon] þareAfturward &punctelev; fair and grene it stod
Seint Daui it honourede muche &punctelev; for he wuste þat it was guod
Þo[MS. þat] seint Daui hadde iwrou&yogh;t &punctelev; þe sunne of lecherie
And manslau&yogh;t, þo for is owene wijf &punctelev; he[MS. þat] het slen vrie
And ore louerd nam þarof wreche &punctelev; swiþe sori he bicam
Onder þat treo is penaunce he dude &punctelev; þat he þarefore nam
Þo makede he þere þene sauter &punctelev; is sunnes forto bete
Þe sonere is sunnes him weren for&yogh;iue &punctelev; for þe holie treo so swete
Þo bigan he also for is sunnes &punctelev; þe holie temple arere
Swiþe noble in Ierusalem &punctelev; ake he deide in þe fourteoþe &yogh;ere
Salomon, his sone &punctelev; þat after him was king þere
Aftur him bulde þe temple forth &punctelev; alþat heo &yogh;are were
to and þritti &yogh;er he was þareaboute &punctelev; and is fader fourtene also
So þat it was sixe and fourti &yogh;er &punctelev; are þat weor[c] was al ido
þo þat weork was almest &yogh;are &punctelev; heom failede a long treo
þat holie treo was fairest þo &punctelev; þat huy mi&yogh;ten ou&yogh;were iseo
¶ Þe kyng Salomon it liet felle and hewe &punctelev; ase quoynteliche ase men mi&yogh;te
And liet it meten and makien more &punctelev; bi a fote þane þe ri&yogh;te
Þo it was ibrou&yogh;t to þe ri&yogh;te stude &punctelev; and scholde beon ilaced þere
Þo was it bi a fote to schort &punctelev; ase euene ase huy it meten er
Þe Carpenters it lieten adon &punctelev; in strongue wrathþe and grete
to no þing þat huy mi&yogh;ten it don &punctelev; it nolde beon imete
Ane brugge ouer ane olde diche &punctelev; huy maden þarof ate laste
For wrathþe þat huy ne mi&yogh;ten in þe temple &punctelev; to none oþure weorke it caste
Þareouer eode mani man &punctelev; þe &yogh;wile it þare lay
Nusten nou&yogh;t alle hov holi it was &punctelev; þat defouleden it al dai
Akneo heo sat and honourede[MS. honoureden] it &punctelev; and nolde nou&yogh;t come þarenei&yogh;.[MS. nou&yogh;t]
bi anoþer wei heo wende forth. &punctelev; to Saloman heo cam
For heo him hadde wel wide isou&yogh;t &punctelev; to leorni of him wisdom
Þoru&yogh; grace þat ore louerd hire &yogh;af &punctelev; to Salomon he[= heo] seide
Þat treo ne scholde nou&yogh;t ligge þere &punctelev; and he dude bi hire rede
&yogh;eot heo seide, þare schal[r. scholde] a man &punctelev; deie on þulke treo
Þoru&yogh; &yogh;wam al þe lawe of giwes &punctelev; destruyd scholde beo
Salomon it liet nimen sone &punctelev; and onder eorþe it caste
Swiþe feor fram alle men &punctelev; and burede hit wel faste
So longue so it þareaftur were &punctelev; a faire welle þare sprong
And a fair &yogh;water with grete fischsches &punctelev; boþe deope and long
Manie sike men þat þare come &punctelev; and wuschschen heore fiet þaron
Oþur heore hondene oþur baþeden Al &punctelev; helþe huy hadden anon
Þat watur huy loueden swiþe muche &punctelev; and wolden þareinne wade
Ake huy nusten nou&yogh;t of þat treo &punctelev; þat al þe vertue made
Sethþe þareafter longue it was &punctelev; þat ore louerd on eorþe cam
Anon so þat folk bispac is deth &punctelev; and heore red þareof nam
Þat treo bigan to fleote &punctelev; ase ore louerdes wille it was
Þe giwes comen and founden þat treo &punctelev; fleotinde þare bi cas
huy nomen it op, for it þou&yogh;te fil and foul &punctelev; and þare hadde ilei&yogh;e longue
And maden þarof þe holie rode &punctelev; ore louerd þaron to hongue
For þat treo forolded was &punctelev; and huy heolden ore louerd luþur also
&YOGH;eot heom þou&yogh;te þat treo to fair &punctelev; þat he were þareon ido
Þe croiz aftur ore louerdes deth &punctelev; deope under eorþe huy caste
Þare ase huy him to deþe duden &punctelev; and bureden it wel faste
And þe tweie croiz also þarebi &punctelev; þat þe þeoues on ihanguede were
Þare huy lei&yogh;en faste ihudde &punctelev; more þane to hondret &yogh;eres
For þo titus and vaspasian &punctelev; Ierusalem nome[r. hadde inome]
And hadden alle þe giwes destruyd &punctelev; þat neuereeft huy þare ne come
And al þat lond was ibrou&yogh;t &punctelev; in þe Aumperoures hond of Rome
And with is men ifuld and al iset &punctelev; to nimen þerto gome
Sethþe þare cam An Aumperour &punctelev; þat hiet Adrian
heþene he was and swiþe luþur &punctelev; and werrede ech cristine man
For he wuste &yogh;ware þe rode lai &punctelev; þat god was on ido
And þat cristine men þe stude honoureden &punctelev; &yogh;wane huy mi&yogh;ten come þerto
he liet ane temple of Maumates &punctelev; in þulke stude arere
Þat men ne mi&yogh;ten nou&yogh;t ifinde to louten heom to &punctelev; bote maumates alle it were
Þei cristine men þudere &yogh;eoden &punctelev; huy ne dorsten oþur for doute
And muche a&yogh;ein heore heorte it was &punctelev; to ani maumete aloute
So þat huy lieten al þulke stude &punctelev; and wenden awei for fere
Þat withinne ane fewe &yogh;eres þereaftur &punctelev; no cristine man ne cam þere
Þo þulke stude was al forlete &punctelev; and þareafter wel mani a dai
Þat cristine man ne paynim &punctelev; nusten &yogh;ware þe rode lai
Sethþe þare cam an[MS. am] Aumperour &punctelev; þat hiet costantin
In weorre and bataylle he was so muche &punctelev; þat þareof nas no fin
Þo come is fon and wonne &punctelev; muche del of is londe
he &yogh;arkede al day al is Ost &punctelev; a&yogh;ein heom forto stonde
ASe he toward þe bataille wende &punctelev; he biheold op and[= an] hei&yogh;
Him þou&yogh;te þat a fair Croiz &punctelev; op in heouene he sei&yogh;
"With þis signe þou schalt maister beo" &punctelev; þulke lettres seden
Þe Aumperour þis Onderstod &punctelev; þei he heþene were
Ane croiz he liet makien sone &punctelev; þat is men bifore him bere
In stude of his baner &punctelev; into þe bataylle anon
And þoru&yogh; vertue of þe holie croiz &punctelev; he ouercam alle is fon
he iwan þe maistrie and al is lond &punctelev; in a luyte stounde þere
[Muche he thouthe þerafterward wat þilke signe were.][This verse is added by a later hand on the margin.]
Þe wiseste men of al is lond &punctelev; he liet bifore him bringue
And Axede heom of þe croyz &punctelev; &yogh;wat were þe tokningue
huy seiden him þat at Ierusalem &punctelev; god was idon on rode
And þe giwes hudden þe croiz þere &punctelev; ase huy onderstode
Of heorte ne worþe ich neuere bliþe &punctelev; are þe holie croyz beo ifounde."
SEint Quiriac, þat Bischop was &punctelev; prechede godes lawe
Þe luþere Aumperour Iulian &punctelev; brou&yogh;te him of dawe
to bilieuen on Iesu crist— &punctelev; for he heold it al wou&yogh;
Þo þe Aumperour hadde seint Quiriac &punctelev; biforen him ibrou&yogh;t
he bad him bilieue on heore Maumates &punctelev; and þo he nolde nou&yogh;t
his ri&yogh;t hond he liet ofsmite &punctelev; And seide, "ich do þe þis
For þou hast þarewith iwrite &punctelev; a&yogh;ein ore lawe, iwis."
"Þou luþere hound," þis oþur seide &punctelev; "wel hast þou idon bi me
Of mine guode þou were wel onderstonde &punctelev; ich au&yogh;te wel blesci þe
For þou me hast[MS. me hast me] þat lime binome &punctelev; þat me hath ofte to sunne idrawe
And ofte ich habbe þarewith iwriten &punctelev; a&yogh;ein Iesu cristes lawe
Þe &yogh;wyle ich was a luþer giv&yogh; &punctelev; and on god ne biliefde nou&yogh;t."
Þo þis Aumperour þat isai&yogh; &punctelev; þat he nolde tuyrne is þou&yogh;t
he made him drinke lead iweld &punctelev; and in is mouth helde it þere
Euere sat þis guode man &punctelev; ri&yogh;t ase him noþing nere
Op one gredire he leide him sethþe &punctelev; ouer a gret fuyr and strong
To rosti ase men doth fersch flesch &punctelev; þat were grece among
Þat fuyr was imaud of col and grece &punctelev; and salt was eke þerto
And is[al. of is] flesch þat was forbrend &punctelev; þe woundene huy selten also
Þo he ne mi&yogh;te þarewith tuyrne is þou&yogh;t &punctelev; and to deþe [him] bringue
he þou&yogh;te &yogh;if he mi&yogh;te him tuyrne &punctelev; with anie oþur þingue
"Quiriac," he seide, "þench on þisulf &punctelev; and do aftur mi lore
&YOGH;if þou nelt ore godes honouri &punctelev; bote þou wolle more
Sei&yogh;e þat þou ne art cristine nou&yogh;t &punctelev; and ichulle debonere beo
Þat murie lijf þou schalt þarafter lede &punctelev; sone þou schalt iseo."
Þo þe guode man nolde aftur him do &punctelev; a Caudron he liet fulle
With eoyle, he liet it seoþe faste &punctelev; and þane guode man þareinne pulle
And seth þareinne þane guode man &punctelev; forto þat he weri was
Þe guode man herede ore louerd euere &punctelev; and neuere þe worse him nas
Þo þe Aumperour þat isai&yogh; &punctelev; þat he ne mi&yogh;te him so ouercome
With a swerd he smot him þoru&yogh; þe heorte &punctelev; þo he was of baþe i|nome
his soule wende to þe Ioye of heouene &punctelev; After is tormentingue
Nou crist for þe loue of seint Quiriac &punctelev; to þulke Ioye us bringue AmeN.
ÞE holie Rode was ifounde &punctelev; ase &yogh;e wutez, in May
He was anhauset in septembre[ 14 Sept.] sethþe &punctelev; on þe holie rodedai&yogh;
Aftur heruest he comez ilome &punctelev; and oþur&yogh;wyle þareInne
god us graunti for his moder loue &punctelev; þe Ioye of heouene iwynne
Mani a &yogh;er þare was bitweone. &punctelev; ri&yogh;t is þat we telle
Of eyþur feste aftur oþur &punctelev; noþur ouerhuppe inelle
A kyng þare was in .perce. þo &punctelev; Cosdroe was is name
Cristine men þat he mi&yogh;te ifinde &punctelev; Alle he brou&yogh;te to schame
With his luþere power he iwan also: þe londes al aboute
And þo he cam to Ierusalem &punctelev; of þe sepulchre he hadde doute
Ake ane partie of þe swete croiz &punctelev; þat seinte [Helene][supplied on the margin.] þudere brou&yogh;te
he tok with him and wende him hom &punctelev; and þudere nonmore ne þou&yogh;te
Of þat treo he was wel prout &punctelev; þei he himsulf luyþur were
A suyþe hei&yogh; tour of gold and seluer &punctelev; he liet him sone arere
Of &yogh;ymmes and of deorewurþe stones &punctelev; þareaboue he liet do
Foourme of sonne and of mone &punctelev; and of steorrene also
Schininde ase þei it heomseolue weren &punctelev; and tuyrne aboute faste
Ase a þondringue he made swyþe ofte &punctelev; þat muche folk ofte agaste
Þoru&yogh; smale holes bi quoyntyse &punctelev; þat watur also þere
Ofte he made to grounde falle &punctelev; ri&yogh;t ase it rein were
Ase feor forth ase ani man couþe &punctelev; he[al. om.] made[al. makie] with quoyntise
Þe fourme ase þei it an heouene were &punctelev; he made on alle wise
Onouewarde þe tour amidde al þis &punctelev; ane sege he liet arere
to sitten himseolf þarinne ase a god &punctelev; in heouene ase þei it were
In his ri&yogh;t half one sege he made &punctelev; his o sone he sette þere
In stude ase þei it were godes sone &punctelev; þat non defaute it nere
In his leoft half he made an oþur &punctelev; and a fair koc he liet fette
And in stude of þe holie gost &punctelev; on his leoft half bi him sette
And he himseolf sat[MS. þat] þareamidde &punctelev; þe fader ase þei it were
Sone and holi gost on eiþur side—: welle, gret pruyte was þere
Eraclius þe Aumperour &punctelev; þat cristine man was, at rome
Of þis[Added on the margin.] misfarinde pruyde &punctelev; he heorde telle ilome
With his host he wende into is lond &punctelev; and weorrede on him wel faste
In his heouene ase a god he sat &punctelev; ase þei him noþing ne agaste
So þat his eldeste sone &punctelev; he hiet wienden atþe laste
Wit his Ost a&yogh;ein þe Aumperour &punctelev; and out of his lond him caste
For he ne deignede nou&yogh;t himseolf for him &punctelev; of his heouene ene a|li&yogh;te
Non more þane hit were a god &punctelev; with eorþeliche manne to fi&yogh;te
his sone a&yogh;ein þe Aumperour &punctelev; with is ost he wende
And þo huy toward þe bataille comen &punctelev; eiþur to oþur sende
Þat huy bitwene heomseoluen tweine &punctelev; þe bataille scholden do
And al heore Ost stonden and biholde &punctelev; and non ne come hem to
&YOGH;weþur of heom aboue were &punctelev; habbe scholde þe mi&yogh;te
Of þe oþeres men and al is lond &punctelev; aftur is wille it di&yogh;te
Þo þis foreward was imad &punctelev; togadere huy smiten to grounde
And fou&yogh;ten ase hit heore ri&yogh;te was &punctelev; and maden heom wel bitere woundes
Atþe laste þe Aumperour &punctelev; þane oþerne ouercam
And al his folk, ase foreward was &punctelev; into his power[al. baundoun] heom nam
he liet heom cristni euerechone &punctelev; and siwi him to is wille
Þe luþere king sat euere at hom &punctelev; in his heouene wel stille
Ase a god, and nuste nou&yogh;t &punctelev; þat he was bineþe ibrou&yogh;t
So vuele he was of his men biloued &punctelev; þat huy nolden him telle nou&yogh;t
Þis Aumperour wende him forth &punctelev; into his heouene an hei&yogh;
And fond him sitten þare ase a god &punctelev; his sone him sat ful nei&yogh;
"Ille hail beo þou, false god &punctelev; in þine false heouene ifounde
bi him þat þou countrefetest &punctelev; þat for us þolede wounde
bote þou wolle on him bilieue &punctelev; þou schalt here in a stounde
Of mine hondene þolie deth &punctelev; and þi pruyte ibrou&yogh;t to grounde
For al þine heouene inelle bileue &punctelev; for marke ne for pounde."
"Nay certes," þis oþur seide &punctelev; "þou ne schalt me so nou&yogh;t lere
Þat ich to anie manne abouwie schulle &punctelev; bote he herre þane ich were."
his &yogh;ongue sone þat sat bi him &punctelev; þat was in his teoþe &yogh;ere
he liet cristny and maken him king &punctelev; of al is fader lond
his men he &yogh;af[MS. &yogh;at] al þat seoluer &punctelev; þat he þere fond
Mid þat gold and þe riche þingues &punctelev; þat he fond also þere
Þe churchene þat þe schrewes destruyden er &punctelev; þarewith he liet arere
And made þare a lond wel bilieued &punctelev; and guod in godes lawe
Alle þat nolden tuyrne to god &punctelev; he brou&yogh;te sone of dawe
Þe holie croiz þat he fond þere &punctelev; þat ore louerd was on ido
Adoun he as nam with gret honour &punctelev; and with him as ladde also
To þe boru&yogh; of Ierusalem. &punctelev; and þo he cam þarebiside
Opon þe hulle of Oliuete &punctelev; one stounde he gan abide
Swyþe muche folk him cam aboute &punctelev; with gret honur withalle
And þonkeden god of þis cas &punctelev; þat heom was þare bifalle
Þat þe swete holie croiz &punctelev; to heom a&yogh;ein moste come
þat þe luyþere kyng Cosdroe &punctelev; heom hadde þare binome
Adoun of þe hulle wende þe Aumperour &punctelev; with fair processioun
Ri&yogh;t þane wei þat ore louerd &yogh;eode &punctelev; toward is passioun
Þo he cam ri&yogh;t to þe boru&yogh; &punctelev; and wolde In atþe &yogh;ate
A fair miracle ore louerd sende &punctelev; þat huy ne mi&yogh;ten In þar ate
For þe stones þat þare weren aboue &punctelev; adoun anon huy ali&yogh;ten
And stoden empne forth ri&yogh;t bi þe oþer walle &punctelev; þat no man In ne mi&yogh;te
Sori was þo þe Aumperour &punctelev; and al is folk also
And adradden þat he nou&yogh;t wuyrþe nere &punctelev; swuch a dede forto do
On god huy criden and wepen sore &punctelev; þat he scholde heom grace siende
&YOGH;if þat it is wille were &punctelev; into þe boru&yogh; forto wiende
þo stod þare An Aungel ouer þe &yogh;ete &punctelev; A croiz he heold on honde
"Sire Aumperour," he seide, "þulke time &punctelev; þat ore louerd was here alonnde
Þo he com in atþusse &yogh;ate &punctelev; to beo to deþe ido
Opon a seli Asse he rod &punctelev; in feble cloþes also
he ne cam with none nobleye &punctelev; so as þou dest nov
With riche cloþes and oþur pruyde &punctelev; þei he were as hei&yogh; as þov."
Mid þis word he wende a&yogh;en. &punctelev; þis Aumperour anon
Ali&yogh;te adoun and his cloþes &punctelev; he caste of euerechon
Anon to is schurte and to is briech &punctelev; sore weopinde withalle
Þe stones arisen op a&yogh;en &punctelev; þat weren er adoun ifalle
And ech lai in his ri&yogh;te stude &punctelev; ase heo hadden er ido
þat &yogh;at was opene ase hit was er &punctelev; þe wei was clene also
Þe Aumperour nam þe swete rode &punctelev; and al afote in bar
Þat folk him siwede with gret pres &punctelev; muche Ioye and blisse was þar
Þare cam anon so swote smul &punctelev; ase hit fram heouene were
Muche was þe suotnesse and þe Ioye &punctelev; þat in þe contreie was þere
"Þis[r. þu] croiz is[om. is] bri&yogh;tore to þis world &punctelev; þane alle þe steorrene beo
Þou art forto honori of alle men &punctelev; and þou art a suyþe louelich treo
holiore þou art þane al þat is &punctelev; for þou one wuyrþe were
Þat þou þat tresor of al þe world &punctelev; al one opon þe þou[om. þou] bere
Þov swete treo þat bere on þe &punctelev; þe swete nayles also
And þe swete burþene of godes sone &punctelev; þat on þe was ido
Saue nouþe al þis compaygnie &punctelev; þat hidere igadered is
And here today togadere ibrou&yogh;t &punctelev; in þine here&yogh;yngue iwis!"
Þe Aumperour song þo þis song &punctelev; þat wel is &yogh;vyt vnderstonde
For &yogh;uyt men it singueth in holie churche &punctelev; &yogh;wane huy berez þe croiz on honde
Al folk onourede also þe croiz &punctelev; so feor forth so huy mi&yogh;ten it do
With offringues and with song &punctelev; and with oþur melodies also
Þoru vertue of þe swete rode &punctelev; anonri&yogh;t in þe place
Mani miracle þare feol aday &punctelev; þoru ore louerdes grace
A ded man aros fram deth to liue &punctelev; and ten men þat meseles were
And four men of strongue palasie &punctelev; heore hele huy hadden ri&yogh;t þere
And fiftene men þat blinde weren &punctelev; and manie oþere also
Þis was þe holie rodeday &punctelev; þat in Septembre is
Þarefore men honouriez in holi churche &punctelev; þulke dai, iwis
Mani miracle of þe swete rode &punctelev; þe man þat heom telle couþe
Þare hath sethþe ibeo and also bifore &punctelev; some we wollez telle nouþe
IN þe lond of costantyne þe noble &punctelev; A gyw sometime þare was
In one churche himseolf al one &punctelev; ase it feol bi cas
he stod and biheol[d] þe rode &punctelev; ore louerd forto schiende
And[r. a = he?] þou&yogh;te to don þe rode schame &punctelev; are eni man come þarehende
In þe þrote with a swerd &punctelev; he smot þe suete rode
Þat blod sprong on him anonri&yogh;t al abrod &punctelev; þat he was al ablode
Þo was þe schrewe aferd of cristine men &punctelev; þat ani come atþe laste
Þe rode he bar anonri&yogh;t awei &punctelev; and in a deop put hire caste
And atorn himseolf for drede. &punctelev; a cristine man sone he mette
Þat biheold him hou he was bibled &punctelev; and on him faste he sette
"Schrewe," he seide, "&yogh;ware hauest þou ibeo? &punctelev; &yogh;wam hast þou i|brou&yogh;t of dawe
Þou schalt abide here with me &punctelev; and beo anhongue oþur todrawe."
"Certes," seide þes oþur, "ine habbe ido &punctelev; no man bote guod."
"Þou lixt," seide þe cristine man &punctelev; "and þat man mai iseo bi þis blod."
"Louerd, merci," seide þe giv&yogh; &punctelev; "to soþe nouþe ich iseo
Þat cristinemannes god is muche and guod &punctelev; betere[al. herre] ne may non beo
doth mid me &yogh;wat &yogh;e wollez &punctelev; ofserued ich habbe iwis
For a rode ich smot a swiþe deop wounde &punctelev; and heo bledde on me þis
And ich eov bidde cristinedom &punctelev; are ich beo to deþe ido."
Cristine men þat þis iheorden &punctelev; ful sone huy &yogh;eoden him to
Of þat þe giv heom tolde &punctelev; huy maden heom ful bold
huy wenden forth and founden þe Rode &punctelev; ase [he] heom hadde itold
huy wuschen hire clene and setten hire up &punctelev; ase heo was er bifore ido
&YOGH;uyt is þe wounde in þe þrote isene &punctelev; and euere heo wole so
Þe giv þat hire hadde so ismite &punctelev; icristned he was sone
And guod lijf ladde, as it bifeol &punctelev; cristine man to done
A Cristine man þare was &yogh;wile &punctelev; in þe londe of Sicie
A rode he hadde in is hous &punctelev; þeron ofte to crie
hit bifeol at is termeday &punctelev; þat he wende to an oþur inne
A giv cam sethþe and wonede þer &punctelev; and nust nou&yogh;t þe rode þareinne
Þo þe rode was þare ifounde &punctelev; alle þe giwes as nome
And ladden as forth to heore Synagogue &punctelev; ase huy ladden ore louerd to dome
And also ase huy ore louerd beoten &punctelev; þe rode huy beoten faste
And spatten on hure and boffatteden also &punctelev; and ofte adoun hire casten
At þe ri&yogh;t side huy smiten a spere &punctelev; ful deope in atþe laste
Þat blod sprong out with gret strem. &punctelev; þo weren þe schrewes agaste
For huy nolden biblede heore synagogue &punctelev; a gret fat and a muche huy fette
to hente þane strem of blode &punctelev; vnder þe rode huy it sette
So þat heo bledde þat fat bretful &punctelev; of blod, are hit stunte
þo ne dorsten huy more schame do &punctelev; þe rode ase huy munte
Ake huy þou&yogh;ten to proui with þat blod &punctelev; &yogh;weþer ore louerd were soth and guod[r. soth god]
Euerech sik giv þat huy kneowen &punctelev; huy smeoreden with þat blod
And heore hele huy hadden anon. &punctelev; þe schrewene onderstode
þat heore lawe nas ri&yogh;t nou&yogh;t &punctelev; þat ne biliefden nou&yogh;t on þe rode
to þe bischop huy wenden anon &punctelev; and lieten heom cristni alle
And tolden al heore luyþere dede &punctelev; ant hou it þareof was bifalle
Þe bischop wuste þis holie blod &punctelev; ase relikes riche and guode
gret miracle þare cam alday &punctelev; of þulke swete blode
So þat it was into manie studes &punctelev; Ifet, wide and side
Þat it is nouþe for relikes iholde &punctelev; in mani a lond wel wide
In mani stude men seggez it is &punctelev; of ore louerdes owene blode
Ake in eche stude it may wel beo &punctelev; among oþere relikes guode
A Giv þare cam to Rome &yogh;wilene &punctelev; þat ne mi&yogh;te herebeorewe non iwinne
In an old hous[MS. hous hous] he lay him adoun &punctelev; feor fram euerech Inne
For he was in so wilde stude &punctelev; of þe deuel he dradde him sore
he þou&yogh;te hou cristine men heom wusten &punctelev; fram þe deoueles lore
With þe croiz he blessede him alaboute &punctelev; anauntre &yogh;wat him bitidde
Þei he þareon ne biliefde nou&yogh;t &punctelev; and lay doun himseolf amidde
A gret deouel þere cam In at midni&yogh;t &punctelev; ase þei it a maister were
And oþur deuelene with him inowe &punctelev; ane chaiere with him huy bere
Þareoppon huy setten þis grete maister &punctelev; and he heom eschte anon
Ech after oþur of heore dedes &punctelev; and &yogh;wareaboute huy hadden igon
Þo euerech hadde i&yogh;olde acountes &punctelev; of schreuhede huy hadden ido
"&YOGH;wat is," he seide, "þilke maister &punctelev; þat ich in þulke huyrne iseo
ho made him so hardi and so wod &punctelev; at oure acounte to beo
goth forth anon and fetteth him hider! &punctelev; we schullen maken him with us telle."
So sore werth þe giv adrad &punctelev; þat he werth nei&yogh; out of is felle
"&YOGH;wat nou?" quath þis bolde maister &punctelev; "&yogh;wy ne habbe &yogh;e him i|brou&yogh;t?"
"Sire, merci," þis oþere seiden &punctelev; "we ne mowen come nei&yogh; him nou&yogh;t
he is in a veteles þat ampti is &punctelev; ake withoute iarmed faste."
Þo flouwen þe deuelene for þe croiz &punctelev; þat sore huy weren agaste
Þe giv biliefde in godes sone &punctelev; þat on þe rode was ido
And liet him cristni also sone &punctelev; so he mi&yogh;te come þerto
A Nonne þare was of on Abbeie &punctelev; þat in a day hire &yogh;eode plei&yogh;e
A fair herbe, þat men cleopez letuse &punctelev; heo isai&yogh; stonde bi þe wei&yogh;e
In hire mouth heo pulte þarof a lef &punctelev; and ne blessede it nou&yogh;t er
heo iwerth anon out of hire witte &punctelev; and feol adoun ri&yogh;t þer
Þat folk made gret deol for hire &punctelev; and ech man þat hire isai&yogh;
An holi man þat þarof heorde &punctelev; þuderward wende adai
Anon so he cam toward hire &punctelev; þe deuel gradde for fere
And seide, "a weilawei! &yogh;wat dude ich here &punctelev; bote op one herbe sat þere
And heo me nam and swaluz[r. swal&yogh;] me in &punctelev; and bot me also wel sore
Þou mi&yogh;t &yogh;wite me &yogh;wat þou wolt &punctelev; ake ine habbe gult non more."
"Þou schalt," quath þis holi man &punctelev; "an oþer.In. habbe to&yogh;ere
For heo for&yogh;at to blessi hure &punctelev; ful redi þou were þere."
Þoru&yogh; signe of þe holie croiz &punctelev; þene deuel he drof out þere
&YOGH;eollinde and fol sori he wende awei &punctelev; with ful grislich bere
Þarefore ich rede ech man beo iwar &punctelev; þat wilnez wel to do
blessi is mete are he it ete &punctelev; þat he ne beo iserued so
Nouþe, god, for þe rode loue &punctelev; þat þou were on ido
bringue us to þe hei&yogh;e Ioye &punctelev; þat þou us bou&yogh;test to. Amen

div1.head: 11. S. Dunstan.[This legend, and S. Cristofer, I have edited before in 'Lemcke, Jahrbuch für rom, und engl. phil., 1875.']

lg.l: SEint Dunston was of enguelonde &punctelev; icome of guode more
Miracle ore louerd dude for him &punctelev; þe &yogh;uyt he was unbore
For þo he was in his moder wombe &punctelev; In a candelmasse day
Þat folk was muche at churche &punctelev; ase hit to þe tyme lay
As huy stoden alle with heore li&yogh;t &punctelev; ri&yogh;t also men stondeth &yogh;uyt nou
heore li&yogh;t queincte oueral &punctelev; þat no mon nuste hou
here þat li&yogh;t barnde swiþe wel &punctelev; and here it was al oute
Þat folk stod al in gret wonder &punctelev; and weren in grete doute
And bispeken ech to oþur &punctelev; in &yogh;wuche manere it were
Þat it queinte so sodeinliche &punctelev; al þat li&yogh;t þat huy bere
Also huy stoden and þarof speken &punctelev; in gret wonder echon
Seint Dunstones moder taper &punctelev; afuyre werth anon
Þat heo huld in hire hond— &punctelev; heo nuste &yogh;wannes it cam
Þat folk stod and þat bihuld &punctelev; and gret wonder þarof it nam
No man nuste fro whannes it cam &punctelev; bote þoru ore louerdes grace
Þarof huy tenden alle heore li&yogh;t &punctelev; þat weren in þe place
&YOGH;wat was þat, þat ore louerd crist &punctelev; fram heouene þat li&yogh;t sende
And þat folk þat þare stode aboute &punctelev; heore taperes þarof tende
Bote þat of þulke holi child &punctelev; þat was in hire wombe þere
Al enguelond scholde beo ili&yogh;t &punctelev; bet þane hit euer er were?
Þo þis child was ibore &punctelev; his freond nomen þerto hede
huy leten hit do to Glastingburi &punctelev; to norischci and to fede
And to techen him his bileue also &punctelev; his pater noster and crede
Þat child wax and wel iþev&yogh; &punctelev; ase it moste nede
To þe world he nam luyte &yogh;eme &punctelev; for to alle godnesse he drou&yogh;
Ech man þat heorde of him speke &punctelev; hadde of him ioye inov&yogh;
Þo he couþe mannes wit &punctelev; to his vncle he gan go
Þe Erchebischop of caunterburi &punctelev; Aldelm þat was þo
With him he maude ioye inov&yogh; &punctelev; and euere þe leng þe more
Þo he isei of his guodnesse &punctelev; and of his wise lore
For gret deinte þat he hadde of him &punctelev; he dude him sone bringue
To þe prince of Engelond &punctelev; Aþelston þe kyngue
Þe king him maude ioye inou&yogh; &punctelev; and grauntede al his bone
Of &yogh;wat þing þat he wolde him bidde &punctelev; &yogh;if it were to done
Seint Dunston him bad ane place &punctelev; þare he was forth ibrou&yogh;t
In þe toun of Glastingburi &punctelev; þat he ne wernde him nou&yogh;t
Þe king grauntede him is bone anon &punctelev; and after him also
Edmund, is broþer, þo he was king &punctelev; and in his power ido
To Glastingburi he wende sone &punctelev; þe guode man seint Dunston
Þo boþe þe kingues &yogh;eue him leue &punctelev; Eadmund and Athelston
¶ A fair Abbeye he let þare arere &punctelev; ase men iseoth þare &yogh;uyt stonde
Of blake Monekes, þat was arerd &punctelev; þe furste of Enguelonde
For ech Abbeie of Enguelonde &punctelev; þat of blake Monekes is
Of þe hous of Gastingburi &punctelev; furst sprong and cam, iwis
Himsulf he nam þe Abite þere &punctelev; and Monek formest bicam
Sone he was Abbot of þe hous &punctelev; and gret couent to him nam
he makede þare godes seruise &punctelev; studefast and stable inov&yogh;
Þis holi Abbod seint Dunston &punctelev; hadde gret power
With þe king Eadmund, þo he was king &punctelev; he was is conseiller
After þe king Eadmundes deþe &punctelev; a guode &yogh;wyle it was agon
Þat Edwyne, is sone, was king imaud &punctelev; ake nou&yogh;t ri&yogh;t sone after anon
¶ Þis Edwyne hadde ful vuel red &punctelev; and þareaftur he drov&yogh;
With seint Dunston he was wroth &punctelev; and with wel gret wov&yogh;
Of his Abbeye he drof him out &punctelev; and dude him schame inov&yogh;
he let driue him out of Enguelonde &punctelev; and let crien him fleme
Þis guode man wende out wel glad &punctelev; ne tok he none &yogh;eme
To þe Abbeie of seint Amaunt &punctelev; bi&yogh;eonde se he drou&yogh;
And soriornede þare longue &punctelev; and ladde guod lijf inov&yogh;
¶ þo þe king Edwyne was ded &punctelev; Edgar, þat was is broþer
After him was king Imaud &punctelev; for he was ner þane ani oþur
Swyþe guod man he bicam &punctelev; and louede wel holi churche
And ech man þat him to guode radde &punctelev; aftur him he gan wurche
¶ Men tolden him of seint Dunston &punctelev; þat is broþer drof out of londe
With vnri&yogh;tht for is guodnesse &punctelev; and he bigan him vnderstonde
After him he sende anon &punctelev; þat he come a&yogh;en sone
And with him bileue is conseiler &punctelev; of þat he hadde to done
Seint Dunston cam hom a&yogh;en &punctelev; and faire was vnderfongue
And hadde his Abbeye al in pays &punctelev; fram &yogh;wuche he hadde ibeo longue
Swyþe wel he was with þe king &punctelev; and al his conseiller
Men speken muche of his guodnesse &punctelev; wel wide feor and ner
¶ Hit bifel þat þe Bischop &punctelev; of wyrecestre was ded
Þe kyng and þe Erchebischop Eode &punctelev; þarof nomen heore red
And þene holie Abbod seint Dunston &punctelev; Bischop huy maden þere
For he scholde beo herre in godes lawe &punctelev; þei it a&yogh;ein is wille were
Some men axeden at þe Erchebischope &punctelev; of Caunterburi sire Ode
&YOGH;warefore þat he him Bischop maude &punctelev; and &yogh;wy his graces weren so guode
"For he schal," seide þis guode Man &punctelev; "aftur me here bee
Erchebischop of Caunterburi &punctelev; and þat Men schullen isee."
"&YOGH;wat wostþou?" þis oþere seiden &punctelev; "þou spext folliche, iwis
Þou nost non more þane þi fot &punctelev; opon god al it is."
"Mine leue frend," seide þis holie Man &punctelev; "&yogh;e ne dorre me blamie nou&yogh;t
For ich wot wel &yogh;wat ore louerd crist &punctelev; in mi Mouth hath ibrou&yogh;t
And hoso withseith ou&yogh;t of þulke þinge &punctelev; þat ich eov habbe ised
Þe soþe he mai seo, &yogh;if he liueth &punctelev; after þat ich am ded."
¶ Bischop he was of londone &punctelev; seint Dunston, sethþe also
Of londone and of wyrecestre &punctelev; and heold boþe to
hit bifel þat þe Erchebischop &punctelev; of Caunterburi was ded
Þe pope and þe king Edgar &punctelev; þarof nomen heore red
And mauden þane guode man seint Dunstan &punctelev; Erchebischop þere
Guode men þat him iknewen &punctelev; wel glade þarof were
Þe cristindom of Enguelonde &punctelev; to guod stat he drov&yogh;
And þe ri&yogh;tes of holi churche &punctelev; he heold up faste inov&yogh;
he fourmede þoru&yogh; al enguelond &punctelev; þat ech person scholde cheose
To witien him chaste fram lecherie &punctelev; oþur his churche leose
Seint Athelwold was þulke tyme &punctelev; Bischop of winchestre
And Oswold, þe guode man &punctelev; Bischop of wurecestre
Þeos twei Bischopes with seint Dunston &punctelev; weren al at one rede
And Edgar þe guode king &punctelev; to done þat guode dede
Þeos þreo Bischopes wenden aboute &punctelev; þoru&yogh; al Enguelonde
And euerech luþer person casten out &punctelev; heom ne mi&yogh;hte non atstonde
heore churchene and heore oþer guod &punctelev; clanliche heom binome
And bisetten as on guode men &punctelev; þoru&yogh; þe popes graunt of rome
Ey&yogh;hte an fourti Abbeies &punctelev; of Monekes and of nonnes

Of þat tresur huy arerden in Enguelonde &punctelev; þat of persones was so iwonne.[Here a leaf is torn out in the MS., with the rest of this and the beginning of the following legend; only the first words of vv. 131151 are preserved on a fragment of the leaf. MS. Vernon, which has the same text, continues:]
[ffor so hit was bet biset &punctelev; þen hit were[al. was] er on schrewe
ffor whonne gode Maystres beoþ &punctelev; sum goodnesse heo wolleþ schewe
Gode weoren þe þreo Bisschopes &punctelev; þat þulke tyme weren þo
Þe betere hit is in Engelonde &punctelev; for hem eueremo
¶ Vr lord &yogh;af seint Dunston &punctelev; on eorþe so feir grace
Þat on a tyme, as he was &punctelev; in a priue place
his ffader and his Modur ek &punctelev; in þe Ioye of heuene anheih
Aftur þat heo weoren dede &punctelev; wel aperteliche he hem seih
Gret loue vr lord him kudde &punctelev; whon he him schewede þere
So muche of his priuyte &punctelev; þe while he alyue were
¶ As he lay a noþur time &punctelev; in his reste a niht
he sayh þe Ioye of heuene &punctelev; and þe place þerinne wel briht
Aungels he herde syngen also &punctelev; a Murie song þerInne
Þat me syngeþ in holy Chirche &punctelev; whon me þe Masse biginne
Kyrie leyson xpe leyson &punctelev; was þat Murie song
Þe holi Mon þat þis iherde &punctelev; hit ne þhouhte him noþing long
Wel ouhte he to heuene come &punctelev; at his endeday
Þat, while he was alyue &punctelev; so muche of heuene he say
¶ harpe he louede swiþe wel &punctelev; for of harpe he couþe inouh
A day he sat in his solas &punctelev; and a lay þeron he drouh
Þe harpe he heng vp bi þe wouh &punctelev; þo hit was tyme to ete
Þo hit was redi þerto ibrouht &punctelev; he sat doun to his mete
Of heuene he gon þenche sone &punctelev; of ioye þat was þere
Of þe Ioyful blisse þat þer was &punctelev; among halewen þat þer were.]
he[These beginnings of the next verses are extant in L. on a fragment of the fol.] sat [as þei&yogh; he weore inome &punctelev; so muche þeron he þouhte.]
his h[arpe, þat heng so bi þe wouh &punctelev; of whom he luyte Rouhte,]
heo gan [to kuiþe his holy þouht &punctelev; ded treo þei&yogh; hit were,]
Also it o[vr lordus wille was— &punctelev; hire herden alle þat weoren þere.]
Al bi hire[self heo gon harpen &punctelev; a Murie Antempne iwis]
Þat men s[ingeþ &yogh;ut in holy churche &punctelev; þat on Englisch is þis]
"halewene s[oulen glade beoþ &punctelev; þat in heuene beoþ ido,]
Þat siweden [vr lordes wey &punctelev; and for him schedden also]
heore blod for [his swete loue. &punctelev; þerfore heo schulen wone]
And kyngues[Vern. knyhtes] be [wiþouten ende &punctelev; wiþ crist Godus sone."]
Þe[al. þis] Antenene þa[t murie is &punctelev; as þis folk iherden alle,]
Þe harpe song a[l bi hireself &punctelev; as heo heng bi þe walle.]
Faire grace ore l[ord him schewede þer &punctelev; whon þat dede treo]
Scholde so singue [of þulke Ioye &punctelev; þat he scholde Inne beo!]
Louerd, ihered beo [þi grace &punctelev; & þi mi&yogh;te also]
Þat woldest her[MS. for] [alyue for him &punctelev; such miracle do.][Vv. 1434, om. in Vern., are added from MS. Harl.]
¶ þo þis holie man [hedde ilyued &punctelev; on eorþe mony a day]
And his endedai [was neih icome &punctelev; as he himself say&yogh;,]
An holi þoresdai [he wex sek &punctelev; as hit fel in þe &yogh;ere.]
he liet him clep[e of his frendes &punctelev; þat specials to hym were,]
his men þat h[im serueden ek &punctelev; he lette hem clepe also,]
[And for&yogh;af hem heore trespas &punctelev; þat heo him hedden misdo
And asoylede hem of heore sunnes &punctelev; as he in Godus bendes lay
And so he lay in þulke tyme &punctelev; and eke þene ffriday
he lette clepe þe saturday &punctelev; þe ffreres biforen him alle
And bad hem alle haue god day &punctelev; and seide what him[r. hem] scholde bifalle
he let him don al his Rihtes &punctelev; and vr lordus flesch he nom
And wende out of þis world &punctelev; and to heuene wel sone com
Now, swete lord seint Dunston &punctelev; þat vre Erchebisschop were
Bring vs to þe Ioye of heuene &punctelev; as Angles þi soule bere. Amen
SEint Augustin, þat cristendom &punctelev; brouhte into Engelonde
Riht is among oþere iwis &punctelev; þat we him vndurstonde
Seint Gregori þe holy Mon &punctelev; pope was of Rome
Engelond he louede muche &punctelev; þeih he þer neuer ne come
Me tolde þat þe lond was good &punctelev; and þat hit heþene was
Wel sori was seint Gregori &punctelev; þat hit cristene nas
himself he wolde habben iwent &punctelev; into Engelonde
Ac he ne moste for þe Cardinals. &punctelev; ac he sende his sonde
Wiþ ffourti goode men &punctelev; seint Austyn he nom
And sende hym into Engelonde &punctelev; to preche cristendom
Þat vchone Monkes weore &punctelev; seint Austin and eke þe oþere
fforþ heo wenden euerichone &punctelev; þat were alle as breþere
Aftur þat God was iboren &punctelev; ffyue hundred &yogh;er hit was
Þat seint Austin wende into Engelonde &punctelev; to do þis goode cas
he dredde him sore for he ne couþe &punctelev; þe speche of Engelonde
he nom men wiþ him þat couþen &punctelev; þe speche vndurstonde
¶ heo duden hem forþ in þe séé. &punctelev; þo heo þider comen
Toward þe heþene of Engelonde &punctelev; þe rihte wey heo nomen
In an Ile bi þe Est &punctelev; Riht atte on ende
Þis Goode Men gonnen aryue &punctelev; as God wol[d]e hem grace sende
Þer heo nomen furst heore In &punctelev; and nomen hem sone to Rede
hou heo mihten best on taken &punctelev; to don þis holy dede
¶ To þe kyng Aþelbert, þat was þo &punctelev; kyng of Engelonde
Bi a qweynte Messager &punctelev; feire heo senden heore sonde
Þat heo weoren Messagers &punctelev; and from an hei&yogh; mon heo come
To don to him a Message &punctelev; from þe Court of Rome
Þat scholde to him world wiþouten ende &punctelev; and to alle in his londe
To gret prou ben and to gret Richesse &punctelev; &yogh;if he hit wolde vndurstonde
¶ Þo þe kyng þis word herde &punctelev; he stod a while in þouht
"Goode tiþinges," he seide, "mot hit beo &punctelev; þat heo me habbeþ ibrouht
vndurfongeþ hem feire inouh &punctelev; and honoureþ hem also
And fyndeþ hem plente inouh &punctelev; of þat heo habbeþ nede to
fforte ich habbe wiþ hem ispeke &punctelev; and heore Message seo
God leue, as heo me bihoteþ &punctelev; þat hit mote to my prou beo."
his heste was ful wel iholde &punctelev; and me vndurfeng hem feire inouh
Þe kyng toward þulke Ile &punctelev; sone þeraftur he him drouh.][Here L. continues, ]
Þo he to þe .yle. cam &punctelev; to seint Austyn he sende
Þat he to him with his felawes &punctelev; to don is erende, iwende
¶ Seint Austyn him greiþede wel &punctelev; and his felawes echon
Forto fi&yogh;hte a&yogh;ein þe Deuel &punctelev; and to batayle gon
huy mauden þe signe of þe croiz— &punctelev; oþure Armes ne hadden huy non
Forto done þis bataille &punctelev; and to ouercome heore fon
Ane Croyz of seluer with þe fourme &punctelev; of god huy leten arere
And in stude of Banere &punctelev; bifore heom huy bere
And &yogh;eoden forth wel baldeliche &punctelev; ase hardie kny&yogh;tes and guode
huy siweden alle heore swete Baner &punctelev; þe fourme of þe rode
Þe letanie huy gonne singue &punctelev; for prov of þe londe
Þat ore swete louerd heom sende grace &punctelev; heore prechingue to vnder|stonde
¶ Þane kyng huy gretten swyþe faire &punctelev; þo huy to him come
And seiden him þe erende &punctelev; þat huy brou&yogh;ten fram þe court of Rome
And precheden him of cristindom &punctelev; and of ore louerdes lawe
Þat[r. to] goddere hele him and alle his &punctelev; &yogh;if huy wolden þareto drawe
huy biheten him þe Ioye of heouene &punctelev; þat so riche was and is
Þat he scholde after þis lijf &punctelev; tuyrne into þulke blis
And be þere withouten ende &punctelev; with god þat us bou&yogh;te
Þe king stod, þo he heorde þis &punctelev; ase þei he were in þou&yogh;te
¶ "Swyþe fair þing," he seide, "it is &punctelev; þat þov bihotest me
Mi&yogh;hte ich beo siker þat hit sothþ were &punctelev; ich wolde don after þe
Ake ich ne concenti nou&yogh;t þerto— &punctelev; for it is &yogh;eot so neowe
Are ich habbe more vnder&yogh;ite &punctelev; &yogh;weþur þis Message beo trewe
Ake for &yogh;e þus itrauailede beoth &punctelev; fram so ferre londe
And for ore guode, ase &yogh;e seggeth &punctelev; and &yogh;e dothþ me onderstonde
Ich eov nelle greui nou&yogh;t &punctelev; ake wel faire bi eov do
And onderfonguen eov and finden also &punctelev; þat &yogh;e habbez neode to
And ich graunti also þat alle þulke &punctelev; þat wollez to eov torne
¶ Seint Austin and alle his &punctelev; A swyþe fair woniingue
In þe toun of Douere he heom &yogh;af &punctelev; to makie inne heore prechingue
Seint Austin and is felawes also &punctelev; bigonne to prechie faste
So þat some þat guode weren &punctelev; to heom heore heorte caste
And turnden heom to cristindom &punctelev; and euere þe leng þe mo
So þat þut folk aboute heom cam &punctelev; ase þicke ase huy mi&yogh;ten go
heore dede sprong so wide sone &punctelev; þat to þe king it cam
Þe faire miracles þat huy duden &punctelev; as huy precheden cristindom
