Some seiden þat Auntecrist &punctelev; oþur is desciples it were
So þat in wel manie studes &punctelev; luyte guod men heom sende
And huy weren ofte ofhungrede sore &punctelev; ase huy aboute wende
So þat huy comen into a stude &punctelev; and ofhungrede weren sore
Þat some of þe freres hadden iþou&yogh;t &punctelev; in þe ordre to beo nonmore
Þo cam þere a wel fair man &punctelev; and brou&yogh;te heom mete inov&yogh;
Þis freres isei&yogh;en fule þo &punctelev; þat an Aungel it was
Þe studefastore in heore ordre &punctelev; huy weren for þis cas
And bihieten god þat huy nolden neuere &punctelev; for miseise ne for wo
In þe ordre bi heore mi&yogh;hte &punctelev; pouerte furgo
¶ Biside þe toun of Asise &punctelev; feor fram eche strete
huy wenden alle to one stude &punctelev; þat was al furlete
Miseyse huy hadden þare inov&yogh; &punctelev; and ofte wepen sore
For defaute of heore sustinaunce &punctelev; and for defaute of bokes more
For huy ne hadde bokes none &punctelev; &yogh;wareon huy mi&yogh;hten loke
In þe croiz huy biheolden al day &punctelev; instude of heore boke
And beden god[MS. guod], &yogh;if it were is wille &punctelev; þat he scholde heom sum guod teche
For huy nadden non oþur bok &punctelev; ne nusten &yogh;warewith any areche
¶ To seinte Marie in desert &punctelev; þannes huy gunne iwiende
Ase huy bigunnen furst þe ordre &punctelev; to bringue as þare to ende
Seint Fraunceis wende bi þe londe &punctelev; and prechede aboute þere
Men wenden, þo huy sei&yogh;en him furst &punctelev; þat of an oþur worlde he were
For he capede euere upward &punctelev; toward heouene an hei&yogh;
Manie heolden him a truant &punctelev; of þe deueles lore
And harleden him here and þer &punctelev; and ofte beten him sore
Þis holie man ne tok none &yogh;eme &punctelev; ake criede ore louerdes ore
And &yogh;ware men duden him mest schame &punctelev; þudere he drov&yogh; þe more
¶ Idel ne kepte he neuere beo &punctelev; he ne louede no þin[g] so luyte
Ne hatede so muche ase he dude Aise &punctelev; and idelnesse and pruyte
"Frere Asse" he cleopede is owene flesch— &punctelev; for &yogh;e wuten wel þat an Asse
Nabbe heo neuere so luyte mete &punctelev; is trauail nis no þe lasse
For heo is iharled here and þere &punctelev; and to file weorke ido
Ipriked and iscourget eke &punctelev; and sackes heo berez also
Of &yogh;eomere þingue heo is ifed &punctelev; &yogh;wane heo alles comez þarto
And selde heo is icoureyd wel &punctelev; withovte nail an scho
¶ He seruede so is owene flesch &punctelev; and cleopede it "frere Asse"
Mete he &yogh;af him luyte inov &punctelev; and to cloþingue wel lasse
he prikede also and scourgede ek &punctelev; and þoru&yogh;out þe contrei&yogh;e
harlede it and deope wod &punctelev; barefot in deope weye
&YOGH;wane he isai&yogh; ani idel Man &punctelev; þat louede glotonie
And ne trauailede nou&yogh;t for is mete &punctelev; he cleopede him "frere flie"
For þe flie ne doth non oþur guod &punctelev; bote fleoth feor and neor
And awaytez &yogh;wane men goth to mete &punctelev; oþur to heore soper
Anon so þe Disch is iset adoun &punctelev; heo wole beo ope þe brerde
Of trauail ne wo ne kep[t]hþ heo nou&yogh;t &punctelev; bote þat heo wel ferde
¶ &YOGH;wane a Man hath al dai iswounke &punctelev; þei he it hadde iswore
he ne schal to is Disch come so sone &punctelev; þat þe flie nele beo bifore
¶ Also farez manie idele Men &punctelev; þat non oþer guod nelleth do
Bote &yogh;wanne oþur Men beth toward þe mete &punctelev; &yogh;are huy beth þarto
Atþe Dische huy wollez also sone beo &punctelev; ase huy þat habbez iswounke
And þanne is al heore weork ido &punctelev; habben huy i&yogh;ete and idronke
Þanne gothþ huy ligge slepe &punctelev; oþur gothþ to some folie
Þarefore seint Fraunceys cleopede &punctelev; swuche men "frere flie"
¶ Of noþing nas þis holie man &punctelev; so glad ase of edwij&yogh;t
For &yogh;wane ani Man opbraid is pouerte &punctelev; he was in gret deli&yogh;t
&YOGH;wane Men cleopeden him hoxtare &punctelev; oþur cheorl oþur cheorles sone
For portMen beoth ofte boistouse &punctelev; and hoxtares bi wone
"leue broþer," he seide &punctelev; "certes, þov seist sothþ
Iblessed beo þou for þat word &punctelev; and alle þat so dothþ
Preses[r. Perses (Ash. Peres)] sone Bernard &punctelev; it bicomethþ bi ri&yogh;the lawe
To heore telle of is ri&yogh;hte &punctelev; ich auch&yogh;te beo glad and fawe."
And &yogh;wane men preiseden ou&yogh;t of is cuynde &punctelev; he nadde þareof no deli&yogh;t
Þarefore hoso wolde him paye &punctelev; segge him sum edwi&yogh;t
And bifore al folk abrod &punctelev; in is prechingue he seide
his Miseise and is defaute &punctelev; ofte and is wrechhede.
¶ In poyle seint Fraunceis &yogh;eode &punctelev; some time ouer lond
So þat a porsful of panes &punctelev; bi þe weie he fond
he ne tok non more &yogh;eme þareto &punctelev; þane to so muche fen
his felawe bad him nimen heom up &punctelev; and dele pouere men
"I nelle nou&yogh;t," seide seint Fraunceis &punctelev; "of oþur mannes dele."
"Me þunchez," seide is felawe þo &punctelev; "þat þov nart nou&yogh;t fele
Þat þou ne louest nou&yogh;t pouere men &punctelev; &yogh;wane þou nelt heom don no guod."
Þis holie man iheorde þis &punctelev; and one &yogh;wile in þou&yogh;te stod
¶ "Þou schalt," he seide, "sone iseo &punctelev; &yogh;[w]at þis panes beoth echon."
he wende and nam up þat pors &punctelev; and openede him anon
Þo crep þare out a naddre &punctelev; þe fouleste þat mi&yogh;hte gon
And þe pors al amti was &punctelev; and peni bilefte non
And þat was þe Deuel of helle &punctelev; þat in þe fourme of panes lay
¶ Þis holie Man seint Fraunceis &punctelev; among ech manere best
Muche he louede &yogh;oungue lambre &punctelev; and anourede heom euere mest
For ore louerd euenede himsulf to a lomb &punctelev; þoru&yogh; seint Iohan þe Baptist
And for it is withoute felonie &punctelev; and milde ase ihesu crist
And ofte &yogh;wane men wolden heom quelle &punctelev; fram deþe he heom brou&yogh;te
With biddingue and with is faire word &punctelev; and fale siþes heom bou&yogh;te
¶ In þe Abbeye of seint verecunde &punctelev; a &yogh;oung lomb he founde
A souwe astrangli it anon &punctelev; and fret it in a stounde
Seint Fraunceis stod and biheold &punctelev; "Among alle bestes," he seide
"Acorsed þou beo, luþere souwe &punctelev; þat dudest þis luþere dede
Þat þi lijf beo schort and strong &punctelev; and þi dethþ beo strong also
And þat no þing ne ete of þi flesch &punctelev; &yogh;wane þou ert of liue ido!"
Þo bigan þe souwe anon &punctelev; ase he þis word seide
To beo ful of schabbe and of buyles &punctelev; and of oþur wrechhede
Þat heo orn out al of quiture &punctelev; and ase þat folk isai&yogh;
In wrechhede and in sorewe inov &punctelev; heo deide þane þridde day
Rauon ne pie no oþur foul &punctelev; nolde enes come þarenei&yogh;
On of is freond for godes loue &punctelev; a lomb him &yogh;ef a day&yogh;
Þis lomb wolde old and &yogh;oung &punctelev; al dai nei&yogh; him beo
And maken with him Ioye inou&yogh; &punctelev; &yogh;wanne it him mi&yogh;hte iseo
Seint Fraunceis hiet þis schep a day &punctelev; &yogh;wanne it heorde freres singue
To churche gon at eche tide &punctelev; and ne lete for none þingue
Þat schep aftur þulke time &punctelev; selde wolde abide
&YOGH;wane hit iheorde freres in þe queor &punctelev; þat hit nas at eche tide
Blete it wolde a&yogh;enes heom &punctelev; for it ne couþe nou&yogh;t elles do
And &yogh;wane ani preost sacrede &punctelev; kneoli it wolde þarto
And wel inwardliche biholde þudere &punctelev; ase it sai&yogh; oþur freres do
Wel au&yogh;te we onouri þe sacringue &punctelev; &yogh;wane a swuch best wolde
A wonder bedeman it was &punctelev; to come to godes[A later hand adds: seruice so] bolde
¶ Ase seint Fraunceis þis holie man &punctelev; ouer lond ofte him drou&yogh;
Wilde foules, smale and grete &punctelev; honoureden him inov&yogh;
For ase he wende in atyme &punctelev; to prechie ouer lond
An hep of foules grete inov&yogh; &punctelev; In a stude he fond
huy songuen and maden noyse inov &punctelev; euerech in is wise
Þe &yogh;uyt þe holie man among heom cam &punctelev; huy nolden nou&yogh;t enes arise
¶ "Beu frere," quath þis holie Man &punctelev; "ore sustren þat beoth here
honourieth god þat heom made &punctelev; ech in his manere
Ri&yogh;ht is þat we don also &punctelev; are we fram heom gon."
huy gonne to segge heore tidene &punctelev; among þis foules echon
Þo maden þis foules so gret noise &punctelev; þat huy ne mi&yogh;hten noþing ihere
"Sostrene," quath þis holie Man &punctelev; "chaungiez eouwer manere
Beothþ nouþe stille and latehþ me segge &punctelev; mine tidene with mi frere
And sethþe &yogh;e mouwen aftur us &punctelev; euerech with is fere."
¶ Þis foules anonri&yogh;ht to is heste &punctelev; stille weren also
And seten and heorden heore tidene &punctelev; forto huy hadden al ido
"Nou sustren," quath þis holie man &punctelev; "we habbuthþ iseid ore tide
Biguynnez ouwer &yogh;wane &yogh;e wollez &punctelev; &yogh;e ne þoruen no leng abide."
Þis foules bigonne singue anon &punctelev; þe leste and eke þe meste
Swiþe gret pouwer he hadde of god &punctelev; þat foules weren at is heste
¶ Þis holie man wende him forth &punctelev; to prechi ouer lond
A gret hep eftsone of foules &punctelev; in on oþur stude he fond
he wende forthþ among heom. &punctelev; þis foules bigonne echon
Louten to him wel mildeliche &punctelev; and honouri him anon
Þis holie Man atstod ane &yogh;wile &punctelev; and þou&yogh;te heom sum guod teche
And ri&yogh;ht ase it weren men of witte &punctelev; þis foules he gan to preche
¶ "Leoue sostrene," he seide, "for godes loue &punctelev; honouriethþ ore creatur
For among alle liues &punctelev; &yogh;e au&yogh;ten him don honour
For he &yogh;ifht eov nobleie inou&yogh; &punctelev; wynguene forto fleo
And feþerene to beren eov upon hei&yogh; &punctelev; wide forto seo
And mete &yogh;ware &yogh;e wollez ali&yogh;hte &punctelev; withoute echemanere suynche
he &yogh;ifth eov also muche pruyte and ayse &punctelev; ase &yogh;e mouwen onne þenche
Delue ne diki ne þorue &yogh;e naþur &punctelev; ase manie Men moten do
And &yogh;eot &yogh;e mouwen habbe mete inov&yogh; &punctelev; &yogh;wane oþere nabbeth nou&yogh;t so."
¶ Þis foules heorkeneden him wel stille &punctelev; þe &yogh;wile is prechingue ilaste
And fram wodes and fram oþur studes &punctelev; þuderword drowen faste
Þo þis holie man hadde ido &punctelev; he wende forth anon
And bitei&yogh;te heom ihesu crist &punctelev; and blessede heom echon
he pleide with heom murie inou&yogh; &punctelev; ase he among heom gan gon,[These vv. are out of order.]
And strokede heom with is longue fleue. &punctelev; þere nolde arise nou&yogh;t on
Are he wolde bidden heom wende forth &punctelev; &yogh;ware huy hadden to done
Þis foules, þo huy heorden þis &punctelev; huy flouwen forth wel sone
¶ Seint Fraunceis among al oþur þingue &punctelev; ri&yogh;ht at is heorte grounde
Ofte he þou&yogh;te deope inov&yogh; &punctelev; of ore louerdes wounden
So studefastliche in is þou&yogh;t &punctelev; non oþur þing he ne nam
hit bifeol at þe holie rodetid &punctelev; þat a&yogh;ein Mi&yogh;helMasse cam
Opon þe hul of Auuerne &punctelev; ase it was ore louerdes wille
Al one in is oresones &punctelev; þere he lai wel stille
he þou&yogh;te on ore louerdes woundene &punctelev; so deope þat it nas non ende
An Aungel he isai&yogh; an hei&yogh; &punctelev; ri&yogh;ht fram heouene wiende
¶ Six wingene him þou&yogh;te he hadde &punctelev; þat schinden bri&yogh;hte and wide
Þe tweie stoden up abouen is heued &punctelev; and þe tweien bi is side
And þoru&yogh;out ouer is wombe acreoyz &punctelev; tweien þere weren also
Ase men seothþ ofte in churche depeint &punctelev; hoso lokethþ þareto
Þe Armes weren along isprad &punctelev; ase huy weren on þe rode
And þe fet istreitht along &punctelev; al vrninde ablode
hit was in fourme of an Aungel &punctelev; ore louerd, ich onderstonde
¶ So gret Ioye hadde þis holie Man &punctelev; of þis noble si&yogh;hte
Þat him þou&yogh;te he was in an oþur world &punctelev; and þonkede godes mi&yogh;hte
he nuste &yogh;wat for Ioye do &punctelev; þe &yogh;wyle he þis fourme isei&yogh;h
At þe laste he fleu&yogh; a&yogh;ein &punctelev; into heouene an hei&yogh;h
Seint Fraunceis was in Ioye inou&yogh; &punctelev; for he hadde þat noble si&yogh;th
And nameliche of ore louerdes wounden &punctelev; þat he wilnede dai&yogh; and ny&yogh;ht
Þo biheold he is owene hondene &punctelev; and is fiet also
Þo weren huy þoru&yogh;out ismite &punctelev; and þe nailes þaron ido
And is ri&yogh;ht side iwounded also— &punctelev; ake wel sore neren huy nou&yogh;t
So þat he hadde þe woundene himsulf &punctelev; þat so muche weren in is þou&yogh;t
¶ Þe nailes weren blake inou&yogh; &punctelev; þe hauedene rounde and grete
Þe poyntes weren euelongue &punctelev; ase huy weren a&yogh;ei[n]wardibete
Aboute þe nailes þat flesch stod up &punctelev; ase it were altoswolle
And ase it al aboute were &punctelev; for Anguyse tobolle
In þis manere we mouwen beo sikere &punctelev; þat ore louerdes woundene were
For bote ase a schewingue and Ansaumple &punctelev; in seint Fraunceyse huy nere
So þat þis holie man hadde &punctelev; ore louerdes woundene fiue
And bilefden on him afturward &punctelev; þe &yogh;wile he was aliue
At þe holie rodetid in Septembre &punctelev; he gan furst þis þing iseo
Ac ope þe hulle he hadde er &punctelev; nei&yogh; a monþe ibeo
And fourtene ni&yogh;t þareafturward &punctelev; he bilefte &yogh;uyt þere
So þat euene vnder al &punctelev; fourti dawes þere were
¶ Ase Moyses opon synay &punctelev; was bi olde dawe
Fourti dai&yogh;es in priuete &punctelev; to seon þe olde lawe
Also was þis holie Man &punctelev; fourti dawes ri&yogh;ht
Opon þe hulle of Auuerne &punctelev; to seo þat holie si&yogh;ht
So þat Aboute Mi&yogh;helmasse &punctelev; furst he wende to grounde
Ac he hudde is fet and hondene faste &punctelev; þat Men ne isei&yogh;en þe wounde
With þe woundene he liuede two &yogh;er &punctelev; and prechede aboute wide
And þe woundene ornen ofte ablode &punctelev; and nameliche of is side
And bibledde is cuyrtel ofte &punctelev; and is briech also
he carede muche hou he mi&yogh;hte &punctelev; stilleliche it awei do.
¶ Sethþe þare cam in þe londe &punctelev; a swyþe strong qualm of orue
Þat schep and reoþeren and oþur bestes &punctelev; aldai lei&yogh;en astorue
A guod Man þat hadde muchel orf &punctelev; bad ore louerd wel faste
Þat he ne binome him nou&yogh;t al is guod &punctelev; ake þat som him moste ilaste
Slepinde in ametingue &punctelev; to him seide þoru&yogh;[om. þoru&yogh;?] godes sonde
Þat he scholde nime of þat watur &punctelev; þat seint Fraunceis wusch inne is honde
Oþur is fet and þerewith &punctelev; among þe bestes sprenge
And, &yogh;if him þou&yogh;te þare were to luyte &punctelev; with oþur watur it Mienge
¶ Þis guode Man þareafturward &punctelev; awaitede is point ofte
And stal of þis watur stilleliche &punctelev; in huydeles wel softe
And spreinde among is owene orf &punctelev; and among oþure mani on
And oueral þare it was ispreind &punctelev; huy weren hole echon.
¶ Seint Fraunceis was frere Menour &punctelev; in þe ordre twenti &yogh;er
And two &yogh;er and almest þreo wyke &punctelev; ore louerdes woundene he ber
On him nas nou&yogh;t bote fel and bon &punctelev; bileued atþe laste
In torment he was strong inov&yogh; &punctelev; and &yogh;wane he was in worst stounde
his lene bones he wolde drawe &punctelev; a&yogh;ein þe harde grounde
Forto make þe more is pine &punctelev; and þe eorþe he custe also
And þonkede god of alle guode &punctelev; þat he him hadde ido
he lay sijk and deide sone &punctelev; seint Fraunceis þe holie man
In ore leuedi churche &punctelev; þare he furst þe ordre bigan
¶ Þo he was þe deþe nei&yogh; &punctelev; naked he liet him do
And to þe harde vrþe al bar &punctelev; al nakede he lay so
And het heom þat aboute him were &punctelev; þat aftur þulke stounde
huy leten him ligge longue also &punctelev; nakede on þe grounde
Þat eorþe mi&yogh;hte on eorþe dei&yogh;e &punctelev; for þat were is ri&yogh;hte
he bigan to prechi is breþren &punctelev; ope is feble mi&yogh;hte
¶ Atþe laste, þo he þene dethþ isai&yogh; &punctelev; and ifelde hine ful strongue
"Voce mea" he bigan &punctelev; one saume of euesongue
And seide forthþ þe saume al out &punctelev; and heold up is hondene hei&yogh;e
And with þe laste word of þe saume &punctelev; he bigan to dei&yogh;e
he deide tweolf hundred &yogh;er &punctelev; and sixe and twenti ri&yogh;ht
Aftur ore louerdes burtime &punctelev; on a saturday at ni&yogh;ht
Þe sonendai he was ibured— &punctelev; he ne ferde nou&yogh;t ase þis riche
Þat for bobaunt of þe world &punctelev; liggethþ longue aliche
¶ Þo þis holie man was ded— &punctelev; þei it were bi ni&yogh;hte
A gret hep of lauerkene &punctelev; opon þe churche ali&yogh;hte
And murie sounguen al þe longue ni&yogh;ht &punctelev; aboute þe bodie þere
Þo þe soule to heouene wende &punctelev; a&yogh;ein kuynde þei it were
For þe lauerke is a foul &punctelev; þat muche louez li&yogh;ht
And herethþ þane dai with hire song &punctelev; and restez hire ani&yogh;ht
A&yogh;ein kuynde huy sounguen þere &punctelev; ase þei huy hadden in muynde
hou muche he was anoured er &punctelev; of foules a&yogh;ein hore kuynde
¶ Frere Austyn, þat was ministre &punctelev; under him ido
Þo þis holie man was ded &punctelev; atþe deþe he lai also
In þe londe of labour[Terra di Lavoro] &punctelev; þat feor was þarebiside
Wel longue he lai specheles &punctelev; þene dethþ forto abide
And ri&yogh;ht ase seint Fraunceis deide &punctelev; feor in an oþur londe
Þis frere Austin spac wel mildeliche &punctelev; and heold up is two honden
"Abijd, broþur," he seide, "ane &yogh;wyle &punctelev; ich come with þe anon."
his freres axeden him &yogh;wat it were— &punctelev; for heom wondrede echon
¶ "Bote frere Fraunceis," he seide, "ore fader &punctelev; ibrou&yogh;t hath is lif to ende
And is nouþe toward heouene &punctelev; and with him ichulle wende."
With þis word he gan dei&yogh;e &punctelev; and is soule al in pes
To þe Ioye of heouene wende &punctelev; with is maister seint Fraunceis
And þare huy [beoth] boþe &punctelev; in Ioye withouten ende
Nou god for þe loue of seint Fraunceis &punctelev; late us alle þudere wende. AmeN
SEint Albon þe holie Man &punctelev; was here of Enguelonde
Imartred he was for godes loue &punctelev; þoru&yogh; Iesu cristes sonde
Formest he was heþene man &punctelev; and of heþene men he cam
And sethþe, ase ore louerd it wolde &punctelev; he tornede to cristindom
¶ Þe luþere prince þat was þo &punctelev; dioclician
And an oþur þat was al so &punctelev; þat hei&yogh;te Maximian
Cristine men þat huy mi&yogh;hten iwite &punctelev; huy brou&yogh;ten alle to grounde
In eche londe huy lieten heom seche &punctelev; &yogh;ware huy mi&yogh;hten beon i|founde
And to strongue deþe heom duden &punctelev; swiþe manie and fale
huy ne spareden none þat huy mi&yogh;hten finde &punctelev; noþur grete ne smale
¶ A luþur Iustise þat with heom was &punctelev; to enguelonde he cam
To Martri alle cristine men &punctelev; and destruyen cristindom
A clerk, a guod cristine man þat was &punctelev; heorde it telle wide
Of tormens þat huy duden oþur men &punctelev; he ne dorste no long abide
To seint Albones house he cam &punctelev; and bad is In þere
hov he was in is oresones &punctelev; boþe ni&yogh;ht and dai&yogh;
he þou&yogh;te þat he was a fol &punctelev; þat he was heþene so longue
he gan to leue on Ihesu crist &punctelev; and cristinedom tafongue
¶ Þe Iustise þane clerk liet seche &punctelev; so þat it was ikud
hou at seint Albones house &punctelev; with him he was ihud
Kni&yogh;htes he sende to fechchen him &punctelev; &yogh;if he ifounde were
To seint Albon huy comen &punctelev; and echsten after him þere.[This v. is written on the margin; v. 256 are spurious.]
huy comen and founden seint Albon &punctelev; and axeden him anon
&YOGH;weþur ani swuch þere were. &punctelev; "for gode," quath þis holie man
"For gode," seide þis guode Man &punctelev; "I nelle it nou&yogh;t forsake
A swuch Man ich am miseolf &punctelev; I nelle eou non oþur take."
¶ "A, þeof," seiden þis luþere men &punctelev; "artþou icome þarto
&YOGH;wane þou wolt for þat strongue þef &punctelev; to deþe beo ido?"
Þis holie man huy bounden faste &punctelev; and to þe Iustise him brou&yogh;te
And tolden him þat he pulte him forth &punctelev; for þat oþur þef þat huy sou&yogh;ten
¶ "Bel ami," quath þe Iustise &punctelev; "seie &yogh;wat is þi name
And of &yogh;wat kunne þou art icome &punctelev; þat ore godes dost schuch[r. swuch] schame."
"To þis Axingue," quath seint Albon &punctelev; "ichulle answerie sone
Of &yogh;wat kunne ich am icome &punctelev; luyte þou hast todone
Alban is mi name, iwis &punctelev; and ich honori also
God þat schop alle þing &punctelev; and eueremore wolle do."
¶ "A, traitur," quath þe Iustise &punctelev; "artþou icome þarto
I schal don tormenti þi bodi &punctelev; fram heued to þin ho
hastþou ihud þane þef athom &punctelev; þat doth us so muche schame
And pulst forthþ þiself, þo[r. þou] cheitif &punctelev; to deþe in his name
Anoure ore godes, ich rede, anon &punctelev; and heom sacrefise
Oþur ichulle þe tormenti so &punctelev; þat men schullen of þe agrise."
"For nou&yogh;t þou spext," quath Albon &punctelev; "þaraboute þou spillest þi brethþ
Inelle neuere þene deuel honoure &punctelev; for drede of þe dethþ."
¶ Þo was þe Iustise swyþe wroth &punctelev; þane holie man he nam
Nakede, and[al. he] liet him faste binde &punctelev; and &yogh;af him sone is dom
With schourges he made is tormentours &punctelev; leggen on him inowe
On him huy leiden þat huy werie weren &punctelev; and al is bodi todrowe
Þe harde scourgene in is tendre flechs &punctelev; deope gonne wade
Þe more þat huy tormenteden him &punctelev; þe gladdore he him made
[534 added in L.]he þonkede god þat he moste &punctelev; þare for is loue
To þe stat of cristindom &punctelev; þoru&yogh; is torment come
¶ þo þe luþere Iustise isai&yogh; &punctelev; þat it was al for nou&yogh;t
Þat he ne mi&yogh;hte fram Iesu crist &punctelev; for noþing torne is þou&yogh;t
he hiet him lede withoute toun &punctelev; and is heued smite of sone
Iredie weren þe tormentours &punctelev; forto do is bone
huy harleden him wel filliche &punctelev; þat schame it was to se
Forto huy comen to þulke stude &punctelev; þare he scholde imartred be
huy comen to an vrninde brok &punctelev; þere huy mosten ouer wade
[634 added in L.]Þe tormentores woden ouer al abrod &punctelev; and no strencþe þarof ne maden
¶ Ake ore louerd for seint Albones loue &punctelev; dude miracle þere
Anon so þe schrewe tormentores &punctelev; ouer iwade were
And ouer þe broke made ane wei &punctelev; druy&yogh;e and clene inou&yogh;
þat he wende ouer also druy&yogh;e &punctelev; ase it alonde were
And euere þat watur bihinden him &punctelev; smot togadere þere
And cam al a&yogh;ein ase it was er &punctelev; þo he cam to londe
Louerd, muche is þi mi&yogh;hte &punctelev; hoso him wole onderstonde
¶ þe maister of þe tormentores &punctelev; to &yogh;wam he was bitake
[734 spurious.]And seide he wolde to Ihesu crist &punctelev; al is heorte wende
For þe Miracle þat he þare isai&yogh; &punctelev; þat so fair was and hende
his sweord þat he on honde bar &punctelev; wel feor fram him he caste
And to seint Albones fet he feol adoun &punctelev; and criede him merci faste
Þat he moste for him dei&yogh;e &punctelev; oþur, bote it oþur were
Þat he moste in þe place &punctelev; þene dethþ afongue þere
¶ Opon an hul huy wenden an hei&yogh; &punctelev; ase huy weren asignet to
Þis holie Man seint Albon &punctelev; to þe deþe do
Ore louerd he bad with guode heorte &punctelev; þat he sende is grace
Þat som water moste to him come &punctelev; in þat ilke place
[856 added in L.]Ore louerd heorde is bone &punctelev; þare anonri&yogh;hte
bifore alle þe tormentores &punctelev; in heore alre si&yogh;hte
¶ For þo he hadde iseid is oresun &punctelev; and ore louerd ibede
Þare sprong out of þat hei&yogh;e [hul] &punctelev; a fair welle in þulke stude
Of also guod water ase ani mi&yogh;hte beo— &punctelev; þat &yogh;uyt lastethþ, ich wene
Euere was þo and also nouþe &punctelev; ore louerdes mi&yogh;hte isene
Þis guode kni&yogh;ht þat biliefde on god &punctelev; for þat he sei&yogh; er
Wel more he criede þo on him &punctelev; for þulke miracle þer
And wilnede &yogh;eorne þat he moste &punctelev; for him dei&yogh;e þere
So þat in ore louerdes name &punctelev; Imartrede boþe huy were
¶ Ake þe tormentour þat smot of &punctelev; seint Albones heued
Luyte he þorte þarof &yogh;elpe &punctelev; him were betere habbe bileued
For þo he smot of is heued &punctelev; ri&yogh;ht in þulke stounde
his owene ey&yogh;ene out of is heued &punctelev; þare ri&yogh;ht fullen to grounde
Louerd, muche is þi mi&yogh;hte &punctelev; hoso him wole onderstonde
Ase men mouwe bi is wiþerwine &punctelev; godes mi&yogh;hte fonde.[g. m. f. on the mar|gin; puyrliche onderstonde ex|punged.]
Seint Albon imartred was &punctelev; here in Enguelonde
Biside ane toune þat widincestre &punctelev; men cleopeden, ich onderstonde
Þare is nouþe a churche arerd &punctelev; and a gret Abbeye also
Þat men cleopieth seint Albones &punctelev; ase he was to deþe ido
Bidde we &yogh;eorne Ihesu crist &punctelev; and seint Albon wel faste
Þat we moten to þe Ioye come &punctelev; þat euere schal ilaste
SEint Wolston, bischop of wyrecestre &punctelev; was here of engelonde
Swiþe holi man he was al is lif &punctelev; ase ich me vnderstonde
Þe &yogh;wile he was a &yogh;ong child &punctelev; clene lif he ladde inov&yogh;
&YOGH;wane oþur children ornen to plei&yogh;e &punctelev; toward churche he drou&yogh;
Seint Edward was kyng þo &punctelev; þat nouþe in heouene is
And þe bischop of wyricestre &punctelev; bri&yogh;ttey hei&yogh;te, iwis
Of þis bischop Bri&yogh;tei &punctelev; seint wolston is ordre nam
Ech aftur oþur, ase it fel &punctelev; so þat he preost bicam
Þe bischop vnderfeng him sethþe &punctelev; and Monek him makede iwis
In þe priorie of wiricestre &punctelev; þat noble hous and gret is
Swyþe wel is ordre he heold &punctelev; in þat priorie
And al is wille was forto pay&yogh;e &punctelev; god and seinte Marie
In none bedde he nolde come &punctelev; ake, &yogh;wane oþere &yogh;eoden þarto
bifore on auter he wolde go &punctelev; his oresones forto do
&YOGH;wane þe dede slep him ouereode &punctelev; þat he ne mi&yogh;te no leng gon
his heued he wolde legge adoun &punctelev; opon þe harde ston
Ope one grece bifore þe Auter &punctelev; oþur is bok þarevnder do
And liggen ane stounde in dweole Miengyngue— &punctelev; al is slep scholde beon so
he nolde þreo dawes in þe wyke &punctelev; noþing eten withalle
Ne no word speken bote his beden &punctelev; for nou&yogh;t þat mi&yogh;te bifalle
þe oþur dawes wel luytel he spak &punctelev; and wel luytel he eat also
bote it were a luyte potage— &punctelev; holde he wolde him þerto
So longue he leouede at wirecestre &punctelev; in þat holie lijf wel stille
Þat he was imaked prior of þat hous &punctelev; muche a&yogh;ein is wille
his Couent he wuste swyþe wel &punctelev; and to alle guodnesse hem drou&yogh;
Of god and alle guode men &punctelev; loue he hadde inou&yogh;
Þe prior[ie][MS. prior] of wyricestre &punctelev; seint oswold bigan er
Þat was bifore seint Wolston &punctelev; nei&yogh; ane hondred &yogh;er
And þat he hadde er bigonne &punctelev; þe oþur fulfulde, iwis
Ase þis holie Man seint wolston &punctelev; in a tyme liet arere
A belhous of swiþe strong weork &punctelev; bellen to hanguy þere
And Machouns aboue and binethe &punctelev; þare aboute were
Bi laddren cloumben up and doun &punctelev; and þat weork bitwene al bere
A man þare clemb up bi one laddre &punctelev; an þo he was up on hei&yogh;
Fram eorþe mo þane fourti fet &punctelev; ase al þat folk isei&yogh;
Dounward he ful, ase he misstap— &punctelev; Men weren sore agaste
Seint wolston stod and biheold &punctelev; hou he was adounward faste
he made þe signe of þe croyz &punctelev; ase he feol toward þe grounde
harmles he feol and hol man inov&yogh; &punctelev; his limes weren hole and sounde
And aros up and dude is weork &punctelev; ase him noþing nere
Louerd, muche is þi mi&yogh;te &punctelev; and þat þou cuddest wel þere
Þat [he] so harde fram so hei&yogh;e feol &punctelev; and of eche harme was sker
Þou art a louerd þat wonderes dest &punctelev; ase seith þe sauter
¶ Hit bifeol so þat bri&yogh;tey &punctelev; þe Bischop of wyricestre, was ded
A clerk was bischop after him &punctelev; þat Men cleopeden aldred
Þat seint wolston louede wel &punctelev; and he louede him also
For ech guod man wole louien oþur &punctelev; it were elles vuele ido
Sethþe it bifel þat þe Erchebischop &punctelev; of Euerwicke was ded
Erchebischop huy maden þar &punctelev; þene bischop aldred
And þe bischopriche of wiricestre &punctelev; vacaunt was and lere
Seint wolston was sone ichose &punctelev; and bischop imaked þere
Bischop him made þe holie man &punctelev; seint Edward þe king
And afeng him in his dignete &punctelev; and tok him is staf and ring
his bischopriche he wuste wel &punctelev; and also is priorie
And aforcede him to serui wel &punctelev; god and seint Marie
Four &yogh;er he hadde bischop ibeo &punctelev; and nou&yogh;t fulliche fiue
þo seint Edward þe holie kyng &punctelev; wende out of þis liue
Gret reuþe it was to al engelond &punctelev; so weilawei þe stounde
For straunge men þere comen sethþe &punctelev; and brou&yogh;ten enguelond to grounde
¶ Harold was þo ri&yogh;htest eyr &punctelev; for non oþur þere nas
Þe croune he bar of Enguelonde &punctelev; &yogh;wuche &yogh;wile so it was
For willame Bastard, þat was þo &punctelev; Eorl in Noremaundie
Þou&yogh;te to winne Enguelond &punctelev; þoru&yogh; strencþe and tricherie
[om.]he let him greiþi folk inou&yogh; &punctelev; and gret poer with [him]1 nam
And with gret strencþe into þe se he him dude &punctelev; and to Enguelonde he cam
he liet ordeinie is fierd wel &punctelev; and is banere up arer[d]e
And destruyde and nam al þat he fond &punctelev; and þat folk sore aferde
¶ Harold heorde herof telle &punctelev; þe king of Enguelonde
he liet greiþie faste is ost &punctelev; a&yogh;ein him forto stonde
Þe baronie of Enguelonde &punctelev; redi was wel sone
Þe king to helpe and heomsulue &punctelev; ase ri&yogh;ht was forto done
Þe weorre was þo in Enguelonde &punctelev; deolful and strong inov&yogh;
And eyþur of oþeres Men &punctelev; alto grounde aslou&yogh;
¶ No strencþe ne hadden þis straunge men &punctelev; þat were icome so newe
A&yogh;einest heom of enguelonde &punctelev; þe &yogh;wyle huy wolden beo trewe
Ake alas þe muchele tricherie &punctelev; þat þo was, and &yogh;eot is
þat brou&yogh;te þo Enguelond &punctelev; alto grounde iwis
For þe englische barones bicomen some &punctelev; ontreowe and false also
To bitrai&yogh;e heomseolf and heore kyng &punctelev; þat so muche heom truste to
¶ Þis Noremauns and þis Englische men &punctelev; ane dai of bataile huy nome
Þare ase þe Abbeie of þe bataille is &punctelev; ate daye togadere huy come
To grounde huy smiten and slowen also. &punctelev; ake alas þulke stounde
Þat Enguelond was þoru&yogh; tresoun &punctelev; þare ibrou&yogh;t to grounde
For þulke þat þe king truste to &punctelev; failleden him wel faste
So þat he was bineoþe ibrou&yogh;t &punctelev; and ouercome atþe laste
And to grounde ibrou&yogh;t, and alle his &punctelev; and al Enguelond also
Into vnecouþe mannes honde &punctelev; þat no ri&yogh;ht ne hadden þarto
And neuereft [it] ne cam a&yogh;ein &punctelev; to ri&yogh;hte Eyres none
Vnkuynde Eyres &yogh;eot huy beothþ &punctelev; ore kingues echone
And nei&yogh;h&yogh;wat alle þis hei&yogh;e Men &punctelev; and of þe lo&yogh;we also
For willam liet [him] crouni king &punctelev; þo þe bataile was al ido
And bisette al enguelond &punctelev; with men of oþere londe
Neuereft to is cuynde heritage &punctelev; ne cam it, ich onderstonde
¶ Þis willam bastard, þat was king &punctelev; sethþe him onderstod
Þat he mid vnri&yogh;hte hadde isched &punctelev; mani ane mannes blod
And þare as þe bataille was &punctelev; ane Abbei&yogh;e he liet arere
Þat "þe Abbeie of þe bataille" is icleoped &punctelev; þat wel noble stand &yogh;eot þere
Ake euere he heold forth þe kynedom &punctelev; of enguelonde with wou&yogh;
¶ Ake sone so he was king imad &punctelev; and al enguelond bisette
Ase he wolde, with straunge men &punctelev; and no man ne mi&yogh;hte him lette
Þis holie Bischop seint wolston &punctelev; wel ofte him withseide
Þat he with onri&yogh;hte hadde ido &punctelev; a swuch luþer dede
And spac a&yogh;ein him baldeliche &punctelev; and ne sparede for no drede
For he was þo þe cuyndeste englische man &punctelev; þat was of enie manhede
And for alle oþure weren deseritede nei&yogh;h. &punctelev; þe king was with heom[r. him] wrothþ
Þat he was so luyte adrad of him &punctelev; and swor anon is othþ
To pulte him out of is bischopriche. &punctelev; he liet [him] somoune also
To westmunstre, to answerien him &punctelev; of þat he him hadde misdo
¶ Nou nas nou&yogh;t seint wulston &punctelev; wel gret clerk in lore
For þo he scholde to scole gon &punctelev; to churche he &yogh;eode wel more
To westmunstre he cam to is day &punctelev; ase he was isomoned er
Þe king was in grete wrathþe &punctelev; wel prest to kepe him þer
And þe bischop of Caunterburi &punctelev; lanfranc was is name
And þe bischop gondolf of Roucestre &punctelev; alle to don him schame
Seint wolston bifore heom cam &punctelev; þat a&yogh;ein him weren so strongue
Ase a þeof bifore Iustise &punctelev; his dom to vnderfongue
¶ Þe king and þe Erchebischop also &punctelev; speken to him wordes grete
Þat he scholde, ase he wuyrþe was &punctelev; is bischopriche lete
Forto holden swuch dignete &punctelev; to luyte he couþe of lore
And huy him hadden to longue iþoled &punctelev; And þo nolden huy nonmore
And grete foles huy weren þat swuch a fol &punctelev; formest brou&yogh;te in swch mi&yogh;hte
And &yogh;if he was folliche onderfongue &punctelev; huy wolden don him out with ri&yogh;hte
¶ Seint wolston stod wel mildeliche &punctelev; and herknede al þat huy sede
Nadde he noman bote god &punctelev; to his answere him rede
"Sires," he seide, "ri&yogh;ht it is &punctelev; þat ich eoure heste do
For, sire king, þou art mi souerein &punctelev; and þe[r. þu] erchebischop also
Þe Croce ich habbe &yogh;are ibore &punctelev; þat &yogh;e iseothþ here, lo
Aknowe ich am and wel ich wot &punctelev; þat inam nou&yogh;t wuyrþe þerto
&YOGH;wane &yogh;e wollez þat ich as bileue &punctelev; ase man þat vnwurþe is
Wel fain ichulle eouwer heste do &punctelev; ase mine souereines, iwis
Vnbou&yogh;hsome to holie churche &punctelev; iwis inelle be nou&yogh;t
To &yogh;elden hire up ase &yogh;e me hotez &punctelev; ich habbe as here ibrou&yogh;t
¶ Ake, for &yogh;e ne token as me nou&yogh;t &punctelev; I nelle eou take non
Ake him þat as me bitok &punctelev; bifore eov euerechon
Þe guode Man þat as me bitok &punctelev; &yogh;eonde he lijthþ wel stille
Ich as wulle him taken up &punctelev; and þanne ich do eoure wille."
¶ To seint Edwardes toumbe he wende &punctelev; þat was of Marbreston
A[r. and?] nam up is croiz wel mildeliche &punctelev; and smot þe point þaron
Þe staf wende into þe marbreston &punctelev; ase it were in nesche sonde
And þo heo was inne deope inou&yogh; &punctelev; þe guode Man hine liet stonde
"Nou," he seide, "ich him habbe bitake &punctelev; him þat as tok me
And bifore eov here &punctelev; i&yogh;ollden op þe dignete
Takez as nouþe &yogh;wam &yogh;e wollez &punctelev; som þat bet beo in lore
And habbez guod dai nouþe euerechone—; &yogh;e ne mouwen esche me nonmore."
¶ Þis holie Man wende forth &punctelev; amon[g] heom alle wel softe
Þat folk stod ase it were inome &punctelev; and biheolden þe croce wel ofte
hou heo stod in þe Marbreston &punctelev; so deope and so faste
Of þe Miracle heom wondrede alle &punctelev; and some weren sore agaste
Some wenden þarto sone &punctelev; þe croce up forto drawe
Þare nas non so strong of heom &punctelev; þat mi&yogh;hte hire enes wawe
huy porueiden er sire Gondolf &punctelev; bischop of roucestre
Þat he scholde aftur seint wolston &punctelev; beon Bischop of wirecestre
¶ Þe Erchebischop aros him up &punctelev; to saisi þe croiz anon
Þe Bischop of Roucestre wel baldeliche &punctelev; þudereward gan gon
Þe croiz he nam and faste he drou&yogh; &punctelev; in þe Marbreston
he ne mi&yogh;hte hire nou&yogh;t enes wawien. &punctelev; þat folk wondrede echon
And þareaboute wel þicke ornen &punctelev; þat wonder forto seo
Þo þe king and þe Erchebischop isei&yogh;en &punctelev; þat non oþur it ne mi&yogh;hte beo
heom ofþou&yogh;te heore dede &punctelev; and after seint wolstan sende
And þat huy wolden in faire manere &punctelev; heore trespas amende
¶ Þe Messagers iredie weren &punctelev; and aftur him sone wenden
&YOGH;eot þis holie Man for al þe gult &punctelev; is heorte to heom bende
And seide, "ich mot nede do &punctelev; mine souereines wille;"
To court he wende a&yogh;ein to heom &punctelev; wel mildeliche and stille
Þo he was to court icome &punctelev; huy arisen a&yogh;ein him þere
Þe king and þe Erchebischop also &punctelev; and oþere þat þare were
With gret honur huy cleopeden him forthþ &punctelev; and for&yogh;iuenesse him bede
And boden amendi a&yogh;ein him &punctelev; al heore grete misdede
And beden him nime a&yogh;ein is croce &punctelev; and don bi heore rede
For he was bet wuyrþe þareto &punctelev; þane ani oþur, huy seide
¶ "Nai certes, sires," quath seint wolston &punctelev; "þat nere me nou&yogh;t to do
Ich wot wel þat &yogh;e seiden soth &punctelev; þat inam nou&yogh;t wuyrþe þareto
Ake nimeth &yogh;wam eower wille be &punctelev; an oþur þat conne more."
Þe kyng and þe Erchebischop also &punctelev; beden him milce and ore
And seiden þat þere nas non oþur &punctelev; þat so wuyrþe were þareto
Longue it was are þis holie man &punctelev; wolde heore wille do[do added later.]
Ake, forto obeien is souereins &punctelev; he wende forth atþe laste
And nam þe croce wel mildeliche &punctelev; þare he stikede hire er so faste
¶ Also li&yogh;htliche ase aniþing &punctelev; þe croce he gan up drawe
Þat so mani men fondeden er &punctelev; and ne mi&yogh;hten hire enes wawe
Þicke orn þat folk abouten him &punctelev; and no wonder it nas
Þe miracle was sone wide ikud &punctelev; þat so apert was
Men anoureden þis holie Man &punctelev; also muche ase huy mi&yogh;hte
his power þat him was er binome &punctelev; he tok a&yogh;ein with ri&yogh;hte
A&yogh;ein to is bischopriche &punctelev; with gret honour he him drou&yogh;
his Couent vnderfeng him faire &punctelev; with grete noblei&yogh;e inou&yogh;
¶ Þis holie Man ladde al is lif &punctelev; swyþe faire and clene
Sijknesses þare weren wel fewe &punctelev; þat man wolde him offe mene
Þat he ne brou&yogh;te to hele anon &punctelev; þoru&yogh; ore louerdes grace
Sike men wel þicke comen &punctelev; to him in eche place
Deue and doumbe and blinde also &punctelev; he helde þoru&yogh; godes grace
&YOGH;wane huy comen to him &punctelev; ou&yogh;were in ani place
So longue he leouede on eorþe here &punctelev; þat he was of grete elde
His bodi bigan to heuegy swiþe &punctelev; grete feblesse he fielde
¶ A slou&yogh; feuere him cam on &punctelev; þat ne nam him nou&yogh;t ful strongue
Ac heo made is bodi to melte awei— &punctelev; þat laste swiþe longue
Seue ni&yogh;ht bifore þat he deide &punctelev; his breþren he liet fette alle
And liet him alle is ri&yogh;htes do &punctelev; and seide &yogh;wat heom scholde bifalle
Out of þis world to heouene he wende &punctelev; þare he schal ay bileue
In þe Monþe of Ieneuer[19 Jan.] &punctelev; aseint Fabianes eue
¶ A þousend &yogh;er and nie hundret &punctelev; and foure þarebifore
It was þat ore swete louerd &punctelev; on vrþe was ibore
In þe teoþe &yogh;ere also &punctelev; of þe kinedom
Of willam þe rede king &punctelev; þat aftur willam bastard cam[These two v. are written in one line.]
he hadde, are he heonne iwende &punctelev; foure and þritti &yogh;er
And four Monþes and four dawes &punctelev; ibeo in worlde[r. wolde? the other MSS. bishop]
Fourscore &yogh;er he was old &punctelev; and seuene also nei&yogh;h
Are he wende out of þis lijf &punctelev; to þe Ioye of heuene an hei&yogh;
¶ Þo þis holie man was ded &punctelev; þe Monekes comen sone
In þe priorie of wirecestre &punctelev; and duden þat was to done
Wuschen þat bodi, ase it was ri&yogh;ht &punctelev; and to churche it bere
Þe Monekes alle with gret honour &punctelev; þat is breþerne were
Þe seruise abouten him huy duden &punctelev; ase it was wel ri&yogh;ht
And to seggen heore sauteres also &punctelev; þarebi huy woken ani&yogh;ht
¶ Þo it was wel withinne ni&yogh;ht &punctelev; ase huy seiden in heore boke
heom luste slepe swiþe wel &punctelev; þat vnneþes huy mi&yogh;hten loke
And some ne mi&yogh;hten nou&yogh;t furbere &punctelev; ake lei&yogh;en and slepen faste
Some ase it were in dweolkningue &punctelev; heore ei&yogh;ene togadere huy caste
Þat holie bodi, þat lai þare ded &punctelev; among heom in þe bere
Aros up wel mildeliche &punctelev; ase þei it aliue were
And awei&yogh;hte heom euerechon &punctelev; and bigan atþon ende
And al along þe rewe &punctelev; þoru&yogh; þe queor he gan iwiende
And euere ase he awei&yogh;hte heom &punctelev; sumdel he[superscr.] gan heom chide
Þat huy nolden with heore slep &punctelev; heore ri&yogh;hte tyme abide
¶ So muche [was] is holi heorte &punctelev; þe ordre forto wite
Þat he nolde, þei he were ded &punctelev; his breþerne fur&yogh;ite
Þis Miracle was sone ikud &punctelev; ase ri&yogh;ht was þat it were
At wirecestre he was ibured &punctelev; and &yogh;uyt he liht þere
Þare Man may for is holie bodi &punctelev; mani fair Miracle iseo
Nou god graunti þat we mote with him &punctelev; in þe Ioye of heouene beo
SEint Matheu þe Ewangelist &punctelev; apostel he was and is,[al. iwis]
Ewangelist and eke apostle &punctelev; forsoþe he was and is
Ewangelist, for he godspelles made &punctelev; þat men doth ofte rede
Apostel, for ore louerd here on vrþe &punctelev; seint Matheu with him gan lede
For ase ore louerd eode ouer lond &punctelev; seint Matheu he sai&yogh; bi cas
his mester don of walkingue &punctelev; for a follare[al. tollare] he was
Fals and trichor of is werk &punctelev; and liuede bi falshede
Ore louerd him hiet bileue is weork &punctelev; "cum siwe me," he seide
And he bilefde þo is weork &punctelev; and wiz ore louerd eode
And is false mester liet &punctelev; for he nadde þerto non neode
¶ Fair forebisne ore louerd &yogh;af &punctelev; alle sunfole men þo
&YOGH;wane he ane so sunfole Man &punctelev; het with him go
Seint Matheu is sunnes bette &punctelev; and tok to cristindom
And siwede ore louerd swiþe faste &punctelev; and is Apostel bicom.
Sethþe þo ore louerd was into &punctelev; heouene iwend
Þe Apostles weren þo wel wide in londe &punctelev; forto prechie, isend
Into þe londe of Ethiope &punctelev; seint Matheu sone &yogh;ede
to prechie men to cristinedom &punctelev; ase it was wel gret neode
¶ He founde tweie luþere men &punctelev; and strongue wichchene þere
Zaroen and Arphaxat &punctelev; þat þe deueles limes were
Þat, ase huy wolden, in grete siknesse &punctelev; manie men hadden ido
And manie men þoru&yogh; þe feonde &punctelev; ihelde huy hadden also
Alle þat þe luþere men &punctelev; in siknesse brou&yogh;te
Seint Matheu heom helde anon &punctelev; and wel clene heom out sou&yogh;te
Sorie weren þis luþere Men &punctelev; huy nusten &yogh;wat was to done
Tweie dragones, þat feondes weren &punctelev; to heom huy cleopeden sone
Þat casten brumston and fuyr &punctelev; and [slowe][om.] &yogh;end al þe londe
Mannes[r. men and] bestes þerewith wel þicke— &punctelev; heom ne mi&yogh;hte no þing at|stonde
¶ Þis luþere men nomen þe dragones to heom &punctelev; for huy scholden to|drawe
Þane Apostel seint Matheu &punctelev; and bringue him of lijfdawe
Þo seint Matheu þis iheorde &punctelev; baldeliche he gan gon
Þe signe he made of þe croiz &punctelev; and to heom wende anon
Anon so þe dragones him isei&yogh;en &punctelev; to is fet huy fullen adoun
huy ne mi&yogh;hten heom wawien hider ne þuder &punctelev; ane fot for al þe toun
"lo, &yogh;e wrechches," quath þe apostle &punctelev; to þe luþere men tweie
"&YOGH;ware is nouþe al eouwere mi&yogh;hte? &punctelev; ouercome &yogh;e beothþ beine
¶ &YOGH;if inadde nouþe mine louerdes grace &punctelev; for eou &yogh;eorne bisou&yogh;t
On eovsulf it scholde nouþe bifalle &punctelev; ase &yogh;e hadden bi me iþou&yogh;t
Þis twei luþere dragones &punctelev; þat &yogh;e habbuth hidere ibrou&yogh;t
Arereth heom &yogh;if &yogh;e mowen &punctelev; oþur eower art nis nou&yogh;t."
¶ Euere stoden þis wrechche men &punctelev; ri&yogh;ht ase huy weren inome
huy weren of seint Matheu aferde sore &punctelev; and heolden heom ouercome
Seint Matheu þis tweie dragones &punctelev; þoru&yogh; Iesu cristes lore
Out of þe londe heom drof anon &punctelev; þat huy ne comen þere nonmore
he wende aboute and prechede &punctelev; and þe tweie schrewene liet go
Ouercomene wrechches ase hui weren &punctelev; nas heom neuer er so wo
¶ Hit bifeol þat þe kingues sone &punctelev; of þe londe was ded
Sone þis twei&yogh;e deoueles limes &punctelev; togadere nomen hore red
And wenden þudere, &yogh;if huy mi&yogh;hten &punctelev; þoru&yogh; heore art him[orig. heom] arere
And huy maden heore enchauntement &punctelev; ase þe deuel heom gan lere
Ake þat child lai euere ded— &punctelev; for heore mi&yogh;hte nas ri&yogh;th nou&yogh;t
Þoru&yogh; þe kingue huy weren inome &punctelev; and in strongue prisone ibrou&yogh;t
¶ Þe king sende aftur seint Matheu &punctelev; ase men of him tolde
&YOGH;if he mi&yogh;hte is sone arere— &punctelev; for he was so wis iholde
Þo seint Matheu þudere cam &punctelev; to ore louerd he[MS. heo] dude is bone
And arerde þat child &punctelev; fram deþe to liue wel sone
Þat child aros and herede god &punctelev; ibore of mayde marie
Anon so þe king þis isei&yogh; &punctelev; wel loude he gan to crie
"Forsoþe," he seide, "ich iseo &punctelev; þat Matheu a god is
Þei he beo here in mannes fourme &punctelev; he is a god, iwis
¶ Anoure we him ase it is ri&yogh;ht &punctelev; with seluer and with golde."
huy offreden to him tresor inou&yogh; &punctelev; more þane he afongue wolde
"Nai certes," quath þis holie man &punctelev; "god nam ich nou&yogh;t
Ake godes seriaunt þat here on eorþe &punctelev; to deþe was ibrou&yogh;t
hoso wole on him bilieue &punctelev; to heouene he schal iwiende
And hoso nele nou&yogh;t, he worth iwis &punctelev; in pine withþouten ende."
So þat þe king and alle his &punctelev; icristnede of him were
With þe tresor þat men him brou&yogh;te &punctelev; a fair churche he liet arere
¶ In þritti dawes heo was arerd— &punctelev; so gret hel[p] þare was to
Þare þe king and is heore beden bede &punctelev; and alþe contrei&yogh;e also
Aftur þe tuei&yogh;e[MS. trei&yogh;e] enchauntours &punctelev; seint Matheu liet sende
Zaroes and Arphaxat &punctelev; and made heom þannes wiende
Into þe londe of perce &punctelev; huy wenden with schame inov
Þere þat folk misbileued &punctelev; wel þicke aboute heom drov
¶ Sethþe seint symon and seint Iude &punctelev; to perce þene wei nome
And þulke two enchauntours &punctelev; to grounde huy ouercome
Þare huy neuereft cristine Men &punctelev; non anuy ne wrou&yogh;te
Ase Man mai in heore liue iseo &punctelev; hoso þareafter sou&yogh;te.
Seint Matheu in Ethiope &punctelev; þe kingues dou&yogh;ter nam
Þat of hireseolf was a clene þing &punctelev; and &yogh;af hire cristinedom
A[r. and?] made hire auouwe chastete &punctelev; and clene lif to lede
þat maide was wel apaid euereafturward &punctelev; of þat ilke dede
¶ A king of an oþur londe &punctelev; is loue on hire he caste
And wolde ire habbe to his spouse &punctelev; and wowede hire wel faste
Þo þis maide nolde is wille do &punctelev; to seint Matheu he &yogh;eode
Þat he scholde in his half beo &punctelev; and bed him grete mede
¶ "Cum," quath seint Matheu, "þilke dai &punctelev; and ich hire wolle rede
Þat heo heolde hire spoushod &punctelev; and þareinne hire lijf lede."
Þe king was glad and wende wel &punctelev; Þat he bi him it seide
Þat he wolde hire to him rede— &punctelev; ake he nolde nou&yogh;t don so to quede
Þe king cam aday, and muche folk &punctelev; with him he gan bringue
And þis maide cam also &punctelev; to hure seint Matheus prechingue
Seint Matheu stod and prechede &punctelev; þat folk al abrod
Mest he preisede of alle þingue &punctelev; in is sarmun spoushod
And þat þere nas no lijf so guod &punctelev; þare it was trewe and clene
Þe kyng was glad and hopede wel &punctelev; þat he it dude bi him mene
For þat Maide scholde &punctelev; to him iwedded beo
Seint Matheu he louede muche &punctelev; and hopede is wille iseo
¶ So þat sethþe seint Matheu &punctelev; is prechingue forþere drou&yogh;
And seide, "&yogh;if þe king hadde a wif &punctelev; þat he louede inou&yogh;
And a fol come in spousbruche &punctelev; and lei&yogh;e bi is wiue
Þe king wolde beo wroth inou&yogh; &punctelev; and bringue him of liue
For he him hadde is wijf binome &punctelev; and imad hire don amis
Of þe hei&yogh;e king of heouene &punctelev; also it fareth, iwis
&YOGH;if he hathþ a guod spouse &punctelev; þat ledeth clene lijf
And þare come forthþ a fol &punctelev; and binime him is wijf
To strongue deþe he wolde him bringue &punctelev; and to þe pine of helle also
Þarefore ech man beo iwar &punctelev; þat he swuch þing ne do."
¶ Þo þe kin[g] iheorde þis &punctelev; sone he onderstod
Þat it was ri&yogh;ht bi him iseid. &punctelev; for wrathþe he was nei&yogh;h wod
And swor þat he nolde bliþe beo &punctelev; are he were[MS. he were a were] awreke
For[th][MS. for] he wende and bigan anon &punctelev; seint Matheus dethþ bispeke
Þis guode man nas noþing aferd &punctelev; he prechede euere faste
And confortede þat clene maide &punctelev; þat ire heorte opon him al caste
¶ Þis Maide feol doun to is fet &punctelev; and on him &yogh;eorne gradde
Euere þis guode man hire bisou&yogh;te &punctelev; þat heo clene lijf ladde
Sethþe he wende and greiþede him &punctelev; is masse forto singue
luþere Men iredie weren &punctelev; isende þoru&yogh; þe kingue
Ri&yogh;ht ase he stod at is Masse &punctelev; on of heom forthþ wende
And smot him þoruout with a swerd &punctelev; and alle his gottes torende
For he smot him In atþe Rugge &punctelev; and atþe wombe out
Þo þe guode Man aslawe was &punctelev; þe schrewe was wel prout
¶ Þat folk þat cristine was &punctelev; wel þicke it cam anon
Þe kingues paleis forto brenne &punctelev; and to aquelle is men echon
Ake seint Matheus desciples &punctelev; forboden heom echone
Þat huy ne duden no such þing &punctelev; ake lieten god wurþe alone
huy wenden and nomen þis holie bodi &punctelev; and swiþe faire on eorþe it brou&yogh;te.
Þe king &yogh;uyt bi al is mi&yogh;te &punctelev; after þat maide &yogh;eorne sou&yogh;te
Ake þo he ne mi&yogh;hte in none manere &punctelev; to is wille hire iwinne
he wende forth and sette afuyre &punctelev; þat hous þat heo was inne
Ake seint Matheu ne for&yogh;at nou&yogh;t þat Maide &punctelev; þei he ded were :[orig. were ded]
Fram heouene he ali&yogh;hte adoun to hire &punctelev; and is help ire cudde þere[added]
For þat fuyr he drof a&yogh;ein &punctelev; to þe kingues paleis anon
And furbrende it alto nou&yogh;t &punctelev; and is Men echon
¶ Vnneþe he himsulf and is sone &punctelev; ascapeden with heore liue
he mi&yogh;hte segge, to wroþerhele &punctelev; he wilne[de] aftur wiue
For suyþe sone þareafturward &punctelev; Musel he bicam
And þo he ne mi&yogh;hte nou&yogh;t beo hol &punctelev; gret deol to him hee nam
With is swerd himsulf he aslou&yogh; &punctelev; and is bodi altorende
Nou god it wot and seint Matheu &punctelev; &yogh;wodere is soule wende
Þat folk wende forth anon &punctelev; and made ane newe king wel bliue
Þe clene maidenes broþur iwis &punctelev; þat he wilnede so muche to wiue
Þat seint Matheu þe apostel hadde &punctelev; icristned with is honde
&YOGH;wareþoru cristinedom &punctelev; cam sethþe into al þe londe
Nou Iesu crist us &yogh;iue is grace &punctelev; þulke Ioy&yogh;e iwinne
For þe loue of seint Matheu &punctelev; þat he woneth inne
SEint leger a bischop was &punctelev; and holi man inou&yogh;
Mani a man þoru&yogh; is prechingue &punctelev; to godes lawe he drou&yogh;
A luþur Iustise þare was nei&yogh;h &punctelev; Ebrom[r. Ebroin] was is name
Men tolden him, ase he wende aboute &punctelev; of seint legeres fame
he liet him wel sone nime &punctelev; and bifore him bringue
And fondede forto tuyrne is þou&yogh;t &punctelev; fram þe heuene kingue
þo he ne mi&yogh;hte þat don nou&yogh;t &punctelev; he was wroth inou&yogh;
¶ Þo is ei&yogh;ene in grete pine &punctelev; weren iholede out boþe
he gan þe more prechi of god. &punctelev; þarefore huy weren wroþe
A wei þer was of scharpe stones &punctelev; and opward stoden echon
Þareoppe þis holie man &punctelev; barefot huy maden gon
huy driuen him barefot and ablend &punctelev; ope þis scharpe stones þere
Þis guode man eode wel baldeliche &punctelev; ase þei him noþing nere
And euere he prechede on Iesu crist— &punctelev; he ne bilefte for no fere
¶ For is longue prechingue þe luþere men &punctelev; wroþest with him were
huy coruen of is tongue anon &punctelev; ri&yogh;ht bi is þrote aboue
Þare schewede ore swete louerd &punctelev; fair Miracle for is loue
For þo is tongue was of icorue &punctelev; &yogh;eot he prechede faste
And also wel as he dude er. &punctelev; þo weren þe schrewes agaste
huy bispeken to don him more schame &punctelev; ake huy weren sumdel in doute
huy [sto]den[unreadable.] and biheolden is heued &punctelev; and þo[MS. þe?] isei&yogh;en huy þare|aboute
A ro[un]d croune and swiþe cler— &punctelev; bri&yogh;htore ne mi&yogh;hte non beo
Þat vnneþe huy mi&yogh;hten is holie heued &punctelev; for þe leome iseo
¶ Þis luþere Iustise het anon &punctelev; þat men smiten of is heued
Four tormentores he was bitake &punctelev; þat it nere nou&yogh;t bileued
huy ladden him withoute toun &punctelev; for[to] don þat dede
Ase huy comen amidde þe wei &punctelev; þis holie man to heom seide
"&YOGH;wat neode is it forto trauailli &punctelev; ferrore me to lede
Dothþ anon þat &yogh;e scholden do &punctelev; here ri&yogh;ht, ich eou rede."
Þe þreo quellares of þis word &punctelev; anon weren in grete drede
To is fet huy feollen akneo &punctelev; and for&yogh;iuenesse him bede
Þarefore was þe feorþe wroth &punctelev; forth he hupte sone
And smot of þe guode mannes heued &punctelev; ase he hadde heste to done
¶ Sone þareaftur cam a fuir &punctelev; ase it of helle were
And al quik furbarnde him &punctelev; and þe deuelene awei him bere
Seint leger was wel faire ibured. &punctelev; is soule to heouene wende
And for þat bodi, ase it on eorþe lai &punctelev; fair miracle ore louerd sende
two &yogh;er aftur þulke tyme &punctelev; þat he him liet aquelle
To is toumbe ane kni&yogh;ht he sende &punctelev; þe soþe forto fonde
Þo þe kni&yogh;ht to þe toumbe cam &punctelev; þarebi he gan stonde
"In schendnesse," he seide, "mote he dei&yogh;e &punctelev; and in strongue deþe also
hoso bilieuethþ þat dede men &punctelev; ani miracle mouwen do!"
Wel filliche also þe toumbe he smot. &punctelev; and anonri&yogh;ht with þe dede
Oppon him feol is owene bone &punctelev; ase he bad and seide
For deuelene astrangleden him anon— &punctelev; for al redie þare huy were
And is soule, ase it was ri&yogh;ht &punctelev; adeuele wei huy bere
¶ Þe Iustise sone þareafturward &punctelev; to deþe was ido
And aslawe in grete schendnesse &punctelev; and adeuele wei wende also
Þus was þe bischop seint leger &punctelev; awreke of is fon
And he himsulf to þe Ioie of heouene &punctelev; after is deþe gan gon
Nou god for þe loue of seint leger &punctelev; is swete grace us siende
Þat we aftur þusse liue &punctelev; moten to þe Ioye of heouene wiende
SEinte Fey, þat holie Maide &punctelev; of swiþe hei&yogh;e men heo com
Swiþe &yogh;ong in hire childhod &punctelev; heo turnede to cristindom
And holi lijf inou heo ladde— &punctelev; þat word sprong wel wide
Of hire guodnesse and of hire holi lijf &punctelev; aboute in eche side
¶ A luþer Aumperour þare was þo &punctelev; þat hiet Dioclician
And is felawe þat was also &punctelev; þe schrewe Maximian
A luþur Iustise huy hadden with heom &punctelev; is name was dacian
To deþe huy brou&yogh;ten &yogh;ware huy founden &punctelev; ani cristine Man
¶ Þe Iustise Dacian &punctelev; wende intal[= into al] þe lond
And aslou&yogh; alle þe cristine men &punctelev; þat he ou&yogh;were fond
So þat he heorde telle &punctelev; ase he wende bi þe wey
Of þis holie maide and clene &punctelev; and icristned, seinte Fey
¶ To þe toune þare heo was inne &punctelev; ase a wod man he wende
And burstinde in grete wrathþe &punctelev; is bedeles aboute he sende
To crie aboute in eche strete &punctelev; &yogh;if men mi&yogh;hte ani finde
Cristine man oþur womman &punctelev; þat huy heom scholden faste binde
And bifore him bringue hasteliche— &punctelev; þat huy ne sparede non!
And bote huy wolden heore [þou&yogh;t] tuyrne &punctelev; anoþur it scholde gon
Ake seoruwe and sor and deol inou&yogh; &punctelev; among cristine men þare was
Þo huy sei&yogh;en heore deth icome &punctelev; and non oþur bote þare nas
¶ Seinte Fey was furst isou&yogh;t &punctelev; for men wusten of hire wel wide
Ioyful heo was and glad inou&yogh; &punctelev; þo men þe banne criede
Ake forth heo wende wel baldeliche &punctelev; nolde heo nou&yogh;t longue abide
Ake profrede hire to þe tormentores &punctelev; ase men sou&yogh;ten hire wide
With hardie heorte heo wende forth. &punctelev; þe tormentores hire nome
And harleden hire wel filliche &punctelev; forth toward hire dome
¶ Þe Iustise for wrathþe wende[r. vemde] þo &punctelev; heo bifore him come
heo made þe signe of þe croiz &punctelev; and blessede hire ilome
heo bad ore louerd wel mildeliche &punctelev; þat he ire &yogh;eue þere
Studefaste bileue and strencþe of heorte &punctelev; þat heo ouercome nere
And in hire tormenz treowe heorte &punctelev; and þat he ire &yogh;eue is grace
To his onour answerie wel &punctelev; þe Iustise in þat place
¶ Þe Iustise biheold þat Maide &punctelev; with ful sori chere
he grennede and femde touward hire &punctelev; ri&yogh;ht ase he wod were
"Dameisele," he seide, "&yogh;wat art þou? &punctelev; &yogh;wat þencstþou forto do
Tel me on &yogh;wam þou bilieuest &punctelev; and &yogh;wat is þi name, also."
"Sire," seide þis holie Maide &punctelev; "Fey ich hote nouþe
And cristine womman ich habbe ibeo &punctelev; sethþe ich ani guod couþe
Mi name nelle ich nou&yogh;t forsake &punctelev; no mi cristindom noþur
Þou mi&yogh;ht þretne al þat þou wolt &punctelev; of me ne worth þe non oþur."
¶ Þo bigan þis Dacian &punctelev; fair semblaunt to make
"Maide," he seide, "ich rede þe &punctelev; þat þou an oþur red take
Þench þat þou art fair and noble &punctelev; and þat þe bet bicome
A noble lauedi to beon and hei&yogh;h &punctelev; þane beo ibrou&yogh;t here to dome
For &yogh;if þou wolt don aftur me &punctelev; in grete Ioie þou worst ibrou&yogh;t
And in grete nobleie, ase þe bicometh— &punctelev; þarefore torne þi þou&yogh;t."
¶ "Certes, sire," þis maide seide &punctelev; "þou spext embe nou&yogh;t
For inelle neuere him forsake &punctelev; þat so deore me hathþ abou&yogh;t
For ich habbe to him mi vou imaked &punctelev; þat inelle neuere breke
Þare[r. þarefore] do elles &yogh;wat þou wolt &punctelev; bote þat þou þarof ne speke
For Inelle nou&yogh;t honouri þine false godes. &punctelev; for in þe sautere it is iwrite
Þat alle swuche Deouele beoth &punctelev; and þat may ech Man iwite."
¶ Þo fierde þe Iustise ase he were wod &punctelev; and made wel sori bere
And was neih&yogh; wod for þis Maide seide &punctelev; þat is godes deuelene were
he liet fette a bed of bras &punctelev; brod and hei&yogh;h also
And dude strepe þis Maide naked &punctelev; and in þis harde bedde ire do
¶ Þis Maide, þo heo naked was &punctelev; with glad semblaunt in wende
huy strei&yogh;hten hire along and acroiz &punctelev; and gret fuyr þareonder tende
And casten on grece riue inou&yogh; &punctelev; þat drof up so gret lei&yogh;e
Þat þis maide þou&yogh;te al afuyre &punctelev; ase huy þat stoden þare isei&yogh;e
Þe tormentores stoden þarebiside &punctelev; with kene oules and strongue
And tur[n]den þat Maide side and oþur &punctelev; ouer þe fuyre wel longue
Euere lai þat holie Maide &punctelev; ase hire nere nou&yogh;t bote guod
hire heu heo nolde chaungi enes &punctelev; ne tuyrne hire þou&yogh;t
Alle men þat þe wonder iseien &punctelev; þe enchesun nusten nou&yogh;t
¶ Cristine men manie &punctelev; þo huy herden telle
Þat þe Iustise was þudere icome &punctelev; with tormenz heom to quelle
huy ornen out of toune hem forto huyde &punctelev; ech in is side, for doute
And lei&yogh;en in puttes and in olde diches &punctelev; &yogh;eont al þe contreie a|boute
An holi man þare hudde him so &punctelev; þat men cleopeden capras
Þat in þe northside of þe toun &punctelev; in one olde roche he was
¶ He lai and darede out of is hole &punctelev; ase he dorste for doute
And isai&yogh; al þe torment of seinte Fey &punctelev; ase he [biheold aboute,[om. (so Ash.)]
hou men rosteden hire with fuyr and grece &punctelev; and todrowen hire also
For it was a luyte þarebiside &punctelev; þat þis dede was ido
Ase þis fuyr bigan to brenne &punctelev; þis holie man isei&yogh;
A coluere þare cam, so &yogh;wijt so milk &punctelev; fram heouene fleo on hei&yogh;
¶ A croune of guold heo bar adoun &punctelev; þat schinde swiþe bri&yogh;hte
Bri&yogh;htore þane þe sonne leom. &punctelev; oppe þe maidenes heued[Ash. maide heo] ali&yogh;hte
And sette þe croune on hire heued &punctelev; with þe winguen heo bleu faste
A&yogh;ein þat fuyr, ase him þou&yogh;te &punctelev; þat it ne mi&yogh;hte nou&yogh;t ilaste
Framward þat Maide heo bleu it euere &punctelev; þat it ne cam hire noþing nei&yogh;h
And heo lai þare in alle Ioye &punctelev; ase þis holie man isei&yogh;h
Þarefore oþure þat weren hire nei&yogh;h &punctelev; nusten nou&yogh;t hou it was
Þat þou&yogh;te þat heo was al afuyre &punctelev; and neuere þe worse hire nas
¶ Þis holie man seint capras &punctelev; þat isei&yogh;h al þis
to himseolf he seide, "ich abide &punctelev; nou sone to longue, iwis;"
he sturte out of þis deope Roche &punctelev; and þudere or[n] wel faste
to þis tormentingue sone he cam &punctelev; noþing him ne agaste
Loude he gradde with folle Mouth &punctelev; "Ich am cristine Man
Inelle forsake Ihesu crist &punctelev; for drede of Dacian
To longue ich habbe heonne ibeo— &punctelev; þat me forþuncheth sore
here is Ioye and blisse inou&yogh;h &punctelev; þat schal bringue us to more."
¶ Tweie breþren þare comen þo also &punctelev; seint Felician
And seint prime &punctelev; þat seide also to þis Dacian
Wodwrothþ was Dacian þo &punctelev; he dude heom nime echon
Seinte Fey and alle þe oþere &punctelev; and smiten of heore heuedes anon
Þe tormentores iredie weren &punctelev; and gonne þat maide take
And hire felawes forth with hire &punctelev; þat nolden ore louerd forsake
And ladden heom forth to heore endeday &punctelev; and heore heuedes smiten of sone
In gret wrathþe ech aftur oþur &punctelev; and duden heore maistres bone
¶ To þe Ioye of heouene anon huy wenden &punctelev; and þare bileue with|outen ende
Aungles þare weren to bere heom forthþ &punctelev; þat ore louerd þudere gan siende
Þe luþere men leten þe bodies ligge &punctelev; þo huy weren ibrou&yogh;t of dawe
In a foul stude al onbured &punctelev; þare bestes heom scholden todrawe
Ake cristine men þat þare weren nei&yogh;h &punctelev; þerto stelen bi ni&yogh;hte
And bureden heom in a derne stude &punctelev; ase nobleliche ase huy mi&yogh;hten
Nou seinte Fey and hire felawes &punctelev; ore erinde beode so
Þat we moten to þe Ioye come &punctelev; þare huy beoth inne ido
Ondleuene þousend of virgines &punctelev; for ore louerd imartrede were
Telle ichulle of heore martyrdom &punctelev; and ho heom þarto gan lere
A kyng þare was in Brutayne &punctelev; sire Maur was is name
Ane dou&yogh;ter he hadde þat hiet Ourse &punctelev; þat was of noble fame
Cristine heo was and al hire kun &punctelev; swiþe hende and quoynte
So fair womman Men nusten non &punctelev; no so guod in euerech pointe
¶ Of hire fairhede and of hire guodnesse &punctelev; men tolden in eche side
Þat þe word cam into Enguelond &punctelev; and elles&yogh;woder wel wide
A kyng þare was þo in Enguelonde &punctelev; and Man of gret poer
Gret nobleie he heorde telle &punctelev; of þis maide feor and ner
his wille was gret þat is sone &punctelev; þis Maide in spoushod hadde
Ake Men þe &yogh;uyt in Enguelond &punctelev; cristinedom non nadden
¶ Þe king of enguelond, þat was þo &punctelev; to þe kyng of Brutayne gan siende
For is dou&yogh;ter to is sone &punctelev; þat was is heyr so hende
And seide, &yogh;if þat he þarea&yogh;en were &punctelev; þat þe dede nere ido
him and alle his he wolde destruy&yogh;e &punctelev; and al his lond also
Þo þis Messagers comen to þis kyng &punctelev; and heore erinde hadden iseid
Sori and dreori was þis king &punctelev; he ne couþe þareof no red
For þe king of Enguelond &punctelev; was heþene, and alle his
And for he wuste wel þat is dou&yogh;hter nolde &punctelev; iwedded beo, iwis
And also, for þe kyng of Enguelond &punctelev; was of so gret mi&yogh;hte
Þat he no strencþe ne mi&yogh;hte habbe &punctelev; a&yogh;ein him forto fi&yogh;hte
And naþeles Triwes of is answere &punctelev; a&yogh;ein þe messagers he nam
Deol and sor and luyte gladnesse &punctelev; in is heorte þare cam
¶ He ne tolde noþing is dou&yogh;ter fore &punctelev; of þis reuful cas
&YOGH;eorne he bad god ni&yogh;ht and day &punctelev; for he redles was
And criede on him swiþe reufulliche &punctelev; þat he him scholde rede
A ni&yogh;ht an Aungel to is dou&yogh;ter cam &punctelev; and þeos wordes to hire sede
"Ne beo þou nou&yogh;ht a&yogh;ein þis sonde &punctelev; Ake, þine fader forto paye
Graunte iwedded forto beo &punctelev; and bide þat he it delai&yogh;e
Ane þreo &yogh;er, þat þou mouwe þe &yogh;wile &punctelev; þi Maidenhod anoure
And þat huy þe purchace clene maidenes &punctelev; with þe to habbe in þi boure
¶ And þat þe king of Enguelonde and is sone &punctelev; and þi fader beon alle at one rede
Þe forto cheose ten clene Maidenes &punctelev; withoute eche wicke dede
&YOGH;wane &yogh;e Endleue togadere beothþ &punctelev; þat huy eou finden &yogh;eot þerto
Euerech of eov a þousend maidenes &punctelev; to serui eou also
Þat &yogh;wane &yogh;e alle togadere beoth &punctelev; þat ech mouwe in is side
honouri hire Maidenhod and þin &punctelev; þat it beo couth wel wide
So þat Men ne mouwen Maide non &punctelev; alosed finde[finde overlined] a&yogh;ein þe
And þat he wolle cristine bicome &punctelev; þi louerd þat schal beo
In þis foreward graunte him &punctelev; aftur þe þridde &yogh;ere
Ispoused to beon in godes lawe— &punctelev; And ne haue þerof no fere!"
Þo þat maide iheorde þis &punctelev; glad heo was of is lore
Þat heo wuste &yogh;warewith heo mi&yogh;hte &punctelev; bringue hire fader of is sore
¶ Sone heo wende to hire fader &punctelev; and bad þat he ire telle scholde
&YOGH;wy þat he so mourninde &yogh;eode. &punctelev; he seide þat he nolde
"Ich wot wel þi þou&yogh;t," þat maide seide &punctelev; "þei þou it holde stille
Of þi sonde ne haue no doute &punctelev; ichulle don al þi wille."
Þo bigan heo tellen him in &yogh;wuche manere— &punctelev; ase þe Aungel hire hadde iseid
heo wolde habbe þene hei&yogh;e Man &punctelev; &yogh;if þat it were is red
¶ Welle, glad was þe kyng &punctelev; þo þat he iheorde þis
Þe Messagers he &yogh;af Answere &punctelev; sone with gret blis
Þo huy [it] brou&yogh;ten þe kingues sone &punctelev; þe tiþingue wel him payde
Sone he liet Baptizen him &punctelev; for loue of þat Maide
And þoru&yogh; is fader and þoru&yogh; him &punctelev; and þoru&yogh; þe oþur kingue
Endleue þousend of clene maidenes &punctelev; to þis maide huy guonne bringue
heo was glad of þe compaygnie &punctelev; þat so fair to hire cam
Sone heo bigan in priueite &punctelev; telle heom of cristinedom
Þat for hire loue and for hire prechingue &punctelev; alle cristine huy were
Louerd, &yogh;wuch a compaygnie &punctelev; of clene maidenes was þere
¶ So gret Ioye þe king of is dou&yogh;ter hadde &punctelev; and of ire faire ferrade
Þat he liet heom makien a quoynte schip &punctelev; of[al. of gret] lengþe and of brede
Þat huy scholden in þe se &punctelev; plei&yogh;e, &yogh;wane huy wolde
Þat ech man alonde and in watere &punctelev; heore maydenhod pre[i]sie scholde
huy sounguen ofte awatere and eke alond &punctelev; and treches huy gonne lede
And oþurmanere faire pleies &punctelev; and al was of clene dedes
Mete and drinke stilleliche &punctelev; to þe schip huy lieten bringue
To þreo &yogh;eres sustinaunce &punctelev; withoute leue of þe kingue
¶ A dai huy wenten into þe se &punctelev; and pleiden heom up and doun
For Ioye þere stoden, to biholden heom &punctelev; Men of mani a toun
Ase huy weren in mest Ioye of plei &punctelev; ore louerd ane wynd sende
Þat drof heom feor into þe se &punctelev; þat men nusten &yogh;wodere huy wende
Welle, glade were þis maydenes þo! &punctelev; þe wind heom drof wel bliue
To[al. ate] þe cite of coloyne &punctelev; formest huy gonne ariue
¶ To Damoysele ourse, þe kyngues dou&yogh;hter &punctelev; an Aungel cam þere
And bad hire lede wel hire compaygnye &punctelev; forto huy imartrede were
And seide þat huy scholden forþere fare &punctelev; and alle a&yogh;ein wende
And in þulke toune for ore louerdes loue &punctelev; imartrede beon atþenende
Glad was þat Mayde for þis word! &punctelev; forthþ huy wenden anon
Atþe cite of Basilie &punctelev; huy ariueden echon
¶ Fram þulke Cite euerechone &punctelev; afote huy wenden to Rome
Gret Ioye made þe pope with heom &punctelev; þo huy þudere come
For manie of heom weren nei&yogh;h him sibbe &punctelev; and for he was of bru|tayne
Cyriac is name was. &punctelev; huy weren of him wel fayne
An Aungel cam to þe pope a ni&yogh;ht &punctelev; and seide þat he scholde
With þis Maydenes imartred beo &punctelev; for ore louerd it so wolde
After þat tyme þis holie man &punctelev; honourede heom þe more
And prechede heom ofte of clannesse &punctelev; and of ore louerdes lore
Tweolf monþe and endleue wokes &punctelev; alle þis Maydenes were
At Rome with þis holie pope &punctelev; þat heom dude wel lere
¶ Ake þe pope seint Ciriac &punctelev; is conseil cleopie gan
His clerkes and is Cardinales &punctelev; and Mani on oþer Man
Bifore heom al is dignete &punctelev; he tok up atþen ende
And seide he wolde into an oþur lond &punctelev; with þis maydenes wende
¶ Þis Cardinales weren þarea&yogh;ein &punctelev; and seiden þat he gan reue
With fole wummen forto go &punctelev; and is dignete bileue
Naþeles he wende forth with heom &punctelev; al a&yogh;ein heore rede
Þe Cardinales and is clerkes &punctelev; gret schame þarefore him seide
Tweie luþere princes þare weren &punctelev; Maximin and Affrican
Þou&yogh;ten þat þis Maydenes wolden &punctelev; tuyrne mani a man
To heore Mey, þe prince of Coloyne &punctelev; huy senden forþenone
Þat he, &yogh;wane huy þudere comen &punctelev; Aslowe heom euerechone
¶ Þat child þat scholde þis Mayde wedde &punctelev; ase heo hadde iseid
Kyng was imaud of Enguelonde &punctelev; þo is fader was ded
Þat ladde swiþe chaste lijf &punctelev; and longuede swiþe sore
With þat clene Maide to speke and beo &punctelev; þoru&yogh; strencþe of godes lore
An Aungel cam to him and bad &punctelev; þat he on alle wise
his Moder and is &yogh;ungueste soster &punctelev; anonri&yogh;ht liete Baptize
And he with heom to Coloygne &punctelev; wiende with al his mayne
A&yogh;ein is trewe spouse, þat was &punctelev; Mayde Ourse of brutayne
Þat heo[r. he] him to hire leide faste &punctelev; in wille and eke in dede
And endede heore lijf in godes seruise &punctelev; ase heo heom wolde rede
¶ þis &yogh;ongue with gret ioye dude &punctelev; þat þe Aungel him gan lere
his moder and is soster he nam &punctelev; þo huy ibaptizede were
And þe Bischop Clement also &punctelev; þat ibaptized heom hadde
Toward coloyne forth with him &punctelev; a&yogh;en þis Maydenes he ladde
Swiþe glad was þis &yogh;ongue king &punctelev; þo he to is lefMan cam
And also glad was þat Maide &punctelev; þo heo sai&yogh;h him in cristinedom
Mest Ioye heo made with is &yogh;ongue soster &punctelev; þat hiet Florentyne
Þat heo, clene Mayde, scholde &punctelev; soffrie deþes pine
¶ Ourse of Brutayne þene &yogh;oungue king &punctelev; in grete Ioye of loue gan lere
Þat he him heolde faste to hire &punctelev; and ne bilefde for no fere
Þat huy mi&yogh;hten in trewe loue &punctelev; togadere imartred beo
And wonye in heuene with Ihesu crist &punctelev; þat bou&yogh;te heom on þe treo
Alþis grauntede þis &yogh;oungue king &punctelev; and is lefmane nou&yogh;t ne wernde
his furste þou&yogh;t into treowe loue &punctelev; and into clannesse he turnde
¶ Þe heþene prince iredi was &punctelev; þo huy to Coloyne come
With manie luþere heþene Men &punctelev; and al þis compaygnie huy nome
And huweden and crieden on heom aschame &punctelev; and to grounde heom aslowe
And ase so fale wolues among lambren &punctelev; heore flechs huy todrowe
Þo huy comen to þis clene þing &punctelev; Maide Ourse of Brutayne
Þat huy founden so fair a creature &punctelev; of hire huy weren wel fayne
Þe prince hire nam and hire bihiet &punctelev; to laten hire gon aliue
And, for heo was so fair and noble &punctelev; habbe hire to wiue
¶ Þis Maide seide þat heo nolde to hire spouse &punctelev; him ne non oþur take
Þe prince nei&yogh;h for wrathþe wod &punctelev; þo he was so fursake
he liet hire to deþe scheote &punctelev; with Aruwene atþenende
And þus heo and al hire compaygnie &punctelev; to þe Ioye of heuene gan wiende
And þe &yogh;ongue king of Enguelonde &punctelev; and is Moder also
And is &yogh;ongue soster Florentine &punctelev; to deþe weren ido
And þe pope Ciriac &punctelev; and Bischopes mani on
Þat for trewe hope of Martyrdom &punctelev; with heom weren igon
Ore louerd hadde swiþe[al. Ou louerd þe] gret Ioye &punctelev; of þat swete ferrede
þat swuch martyrdom for is[al. þi] loue &punctelev; afenguen withoute drede
In þe to hondrede &yogh;ere[al. om.] &punctelev; and ei&yogh;te and þrittiþe &yogh;ere
After ore louerdes buyrtyme &punctelev; þis maidenes imartrede were
¶ Þis endleue þousend of clene maydenes &punctelev; and al þis compaygnie
Iburede weren in Coloyne &punctelev; in one Nonnerie.
An Abbot þere was biside &punctelev; þat heorde of þis cas
And ofte of þis clene Maydenes &punctelev; þat gret Miracle þere was
he bad þe Abbesse of Coloyne &punctelev; þat heo him graunti scholde
A bodi of þis clene Maydenes &punctelev; and he wolde it don in golde
Þo þis bodi was him itake &punctelev; twelf Monþe he liet it beo
Withoute seluer oþur gold &punctelev; in one cheste of treo
¶ Þo þe twelf monþes weren ago &punctelev; ase þe Monekes weren echone
A ny&yogh;t at Matines, þis[MS. þis þis] holie bodi &punctelev; aros hire up allone
heo beu&yogh; hire to þe hei&yogh;e weued &punctelev; and wende mildeliche
Among al þe Couent forthþ &punctelev; and out wel stilledliche.[r. stilleliche]
Þe Monekus, þo huy þis isei&yogh;en &punctelev; ofdradde and sorien[r. sorie] were
huy eoden to þe cheste þare heo [was] inne ileid &punctelev; and ne founden ire nou&yogh;t þere
¶ "Þis," quath þe Abbod, "is ore wreche &punctelev; for we hire ido nadde
In a schrine of gold, ase we biheten &punctelev; þo we ire hidere ladden."
To þe Abbesse of Coloyne &punctelev; þe Abbod wende anon
And tolde þis cas alhou it was &punctelev; of þat Maide igon
huy wenden forthþ to þulke stude &punctelev; þare heo was ileid inne er
And heuen up þe þrouwes lid &punctelev; and founden hire ligge þer
Faire and euene ase heo dude er— &punctelev; so luyte lime þere nas
Þat ne lai ase heo was furst ileid. &punctelev; a fair Miracle þere was
Þe Abbesse was þo swyþe glad &punctelev; and þe Nonnes euerechon
And þonkede god of þat faire Miracle &punctelev; and hei&yogh;e sounguen anon
¶ Þe Abbot bad þat he moste habbe &punctelev; þis holie bodi eftsone
And seide he wolde honouri it faire &punctelev; ase he au&yogh;te forto done
Ake þe Abbesse nolde graunti it nou&yogh;t &punctelev; ne þat couent noþur
Þat eft it scholde habbe awei &punctelev; þei he hadde ibeo heore broþur
For buy isei&yogh;en þat it was godes wille &punctelev; þat it bilefde þere
Þis Abbod wende him hom a&yogh;ein &punctelev; with wel dreorie chere
Nou God us graunti, &yogh;if is wille is &punctelev; þat we moten iwinne
Þe hei&yogh;e Ioye of heouene &punctelev; þare alle þis Maydenes beoth inne
Ne þat we neuere þarof ne missen &punctelev; for none[MS. nome] sorie sunne
SEinte Katerine of noble kunne: cam, bi olde dawe
Hire fader was king, hire Moder Quyene &punctelev; boþe of þe olde lawe
Þe king . Coste. hire fader het. &punctelev; gret clerk þis Mayde was
Þare nas non of þe seue .Ars &punctelev; þat heo maister of nas
Maxentius het þe Aumperour &punctelev; In eche londe he let crie
Þat ech kynerich under him &punctelev; come to Alisaundrie
Euerech Man for is stat &punctelev; to don to heore godes sacrefise
hoso it lete, men scholde of him don &punctelev; swyþe stronge Iustise
Þo ech lond was þudere icome &punctelev; to don heore lawe
Seinte katerine wel hardeliche &punctelev; toward heom gan drawe
bihalues heo stod and biheold &punctelev; heore wrechche gydihede
heo sai&yogh; Anouri þe Maumates &punctelev; and manie cristine Men for drede
Þo hadde heo gret deol in hire heorte &punctelev; and blesse[de] hire anon
And forth anon to þe Aumperour &punctelev; baldeliche heo gan gon
"Sire," heo seide, "riche Aumperour þou art &punctelev; swiþe noble and hende
Þov scholdest þi wisdom and þi wit &punctelev; to some guode wende
Þat i segge for þe folie &punctelev; þat ich iseo eov do
So muche feorrene folk &punctelev; þov hast icleopet þarto
Grete Ioie in ouwer heorte &punctelev; þis temple &yogh;e makiez ifo
Þat is ymaud of lym and ston &punctelev; and of ouwer Maumates also
&YOGH;wy ne biholde &yogh;e þe hei&yogh;e temple— &punctelev; for þerof wondri ov mai
Of þe heie heuene þat geth aboute &punctelev; abouen eov ni&yogh;t and dai
Of sonne and Mone and steorrene also &punctelev; fram þe este to þe weste
Þat trauaillieth and neuere werie ne beoth &punctelev; ne neuere ne habbeth reste
biþench þe wel and turne þi wit &punctelev; to some wisdome, ich rede
And &yogh;wane þin owene Inwit it seith &punctelev; þat nou&yogh;were nis swuch dede
Almi&yogh;ti god þou him hold &punctelev; þat swuch wonder can make
bifore alle oþere Anoure him &punctelev; and þine Maumates forsake."
With oþere resones of clergie &punctelev; þat mayde proffrede also
Þat heore godes nau&yogh;tes ne were &punctelev; þat heo Anoureden heom to
¶ Þe Aumperour stod and ne couþe þarto &punctelev; Answerie In none wise
Gret wonder him þou&yogh;te of hire fairhede &punctelev; and of hire Quoyntise
"Mayde," he seide, "abijd herewith &punctelev; forto aftur ore sacrefise
And we schullen more with þe speke &punctelev; ich oþur mi Iustise."
Þo þe sacrefise was idon &punctelev; þe Aumperour sat In is trone
And al is folk abouten him. &punctelev; men brouten þat Maide sone
"Maide," seide þe Aumperur &punctelev; "þou þinchest gent and freo
Of &yogh;wat kunrade art þou icome? &punctelev; gret wonder us þinchez of þe."
¶ "Sire Aumperur," þis Maide seide &punctelev; "Ine wilni bote luyte
to tellen þe of mine kunne &punctelev; for it were signe of pruyte
For In is boke þe wise Man &punctelev; Catun seith also
Þat Man ne schal himsulue preisi &punctelev; ne blamie noþemo
